Compare information from multiple sources to verify facts and identify any discrepancies.
Determine whether an author has potential bias based on their affiliations or the publication's purpose.
Assess whether a source provides evidence and citations for its claims or makes unsupported assertions.
Decide whether a source is appropriate for academic research based on its credibility, relevance, and publication type.

sub_topics.name: Selecting Relevant Information
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying which information from sources directly addresses research questions.
example_tasks: Skim multiple sources to determine which contain information relevant to your specific research question.
Identify the most important facts, statistics, or expert opinions from a source that support your research.
Determine which sections of a longer source are relevant to your needs and which can be skipped.
Evaluate whether information is directly relevant, somewhat related, or not useful for your research question.
Select the best evidence from multiple sources, choosing the most current, specific, or authoritative information.

sub_topics.name: Using Multiple Sources
sub_topics.short_description: Consulting various sources to gain comprehensive understanding and diverse perspectives.
example_tasks: Gather information from at least five different sources representing different types (books, articles, websites).
Consult sources that present different perspectives on a controversial issue.
Use both primary sources (original documents, interviews) and secondary sources (analyses, textbooks) in your research.
Compare how different sources treat the same topic and note areas of agreement and disagreement.
Ensure you have consulted authoritative, scholarly sources rather than relying solely on general websites.

sub_topics.name: Synthesizing and Integrating Information from Sources
sub_topics.short_description: Combining information from multiple sources and incorporating it effectively into writing.

sub_topics.name: Taking Effective Research Notes
sub_topics.short_description: Recording information from sources accurately while tracking sources for citation.
example_tasks: Take notes on index cards or digital notes, recording one main idea per card along with source information.
Use a note-taking system that distinguishes between direct quotes, paraphrases, and your own ideas.
Record complete bibliographic information for each source as you take notes.
Organize notes by subtopic or research question to make synthesizing information easier.
Summarize main ideas from sources in your own words while noting page numbers for later citation.

sub_topics.name: Quoting, Paraphrasing, and Summarizing
sub_topics.short_description: Representing source information accurately through direct quotation, paraphrase, or summary.
example_tasks: Decide whether to quote directly, paraphrase, or summarize based on the importance and wording of the original.
Quote directly when the author's exact wording is particularly powerful or precise.
Paraphrase information from a source by completely restating ideas in your own words and sentence structure.
Write a one-paragraph summary that captures the main ideas from a three-page article.
Avoid plagiarism by ensuring your paraphrase doesn't just substitute a few synonyms but truly restates the idea.

sub_topics.name: Integrating Sources into Writing
sub_topics.short_description: Incorporating evidence from sources smoothly and effectively into your own prose.
example_tasks: Introduce quotations with signal phrases that provide context (According to historian Jane Smith...).
Integrate a quote into your own sentence structure rather than dropping it in abruptly.
Follow quotations or paraphrases with your own analysis explaining how the evidence supports your point.
Balance source material with your own ideas so the paper represents your thinking, not just a compilation of quotes.
Use a variety of verbs in signal phrases (argues, suggests, demonstrates, explains) rather than repeating 'says.'

sub_topics.name: Synthesizing Information from Multiple Sources
sub_topics.short_description: Combining ideas from different sources to create new understanding or support arguments.
example_tasks: Write a paragraph that synthesizes information from three different sources on the same topic.
Compare and contrast what different sources say about an issue, noting agreements and disagreements.
Draw a conclusion based on evidence gathered from multiple sources.
Identify patterns or themes that emerge when reading several sources on the same topic.
Create a comprehensive explanation of a topic by combining unique information from different sources.

sub_topics.name: Avoiding Plagiarism and Citing Sources
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding academic integrity and properly crediting sources following standard citation formats.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Plagiarism and Academic Integrity
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing what constitutes plagiarism and why proper attribution is essential.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between quoting, paraphrasing, summarizing, and plagiarizing with specific examples.
Identify instances of plagiarism in sample texts (copying without quotes, improper paraphrasing, missing citations).
Understand that plagiarism includes using ideas, not just exact words, without giving credit.
Recognize that accidental plagiarism is still plagiarism and learn strategies to avoid it.
Explain why academic integrity matters and how plagiarism violates ethical standards and trust.

sub_topics.name: Using In-Text Citations
sub_topics.short_description: Providing parenthetical citations or footnotes to credit sources within the text.
example_tasks: Add MLA in-text citations after quotations and paraphrases (Author page number) in your research paper.
Use signal phrases combined with parenthetical citations to integrate sources smoothly.
Correctly cite sources with multiple authors, no author, or corporate authors following MLA format.
Place in-text citations appropriately (before the period for short quotes, after for block quotes).
Ensure every fact, statistic, or idea from a source has an appropriate citation.

sub_topics.name: Creating Works Cited and Bibliographies
sub_topics.short_description: Compiling complete citation information for all sources in proper format.
example_tasks: Create an MLA Works Cited page with correct formatting (hanging indent, alphabetical order, proper punctuation).
Write citations for different source types (books, articles, websites, videos) following MLA format.
Include all required elements in each citation (author, title, publication information, access date for websites).
Format online source citations correctly, including URLs and access dates when required.
Ensure every source cited in your paper appears in the Works Cited and vice versa.

sub_topics.name: Using Citation Tools and Resources
sub_topics.short_description: Employing handbooks, websites, and citation generators to create accurate citations.
example_tasks: Use a citation handbook or reliable website (Purdue OWL) to check proper MLA format for various source types.
Use a citation generator to create citations, but verify accuracy by checking against official guidelines.
Consult your teacher or librarian when you encounter an unusual source type you're not sure how to cite.
Keep a style guide handy while writing to quickly check citation rules as needed.
Learn the basic pattern of MLA citations so you can create accurate citations even without tools.

name: Writing - Range of Writing
short_description: Students write routinely over extended and shorter time frames for various purposes and audiences. They develop flexibility in adapting their writing process to different tasks and deadlines.

sub_topics.name: Writing Over Extended Time Frames
sub_topics.short_description: Completing substantial writing projects that involve research, planning, multiple drafts, and revision.

sub_topics.name: Extended Research Papers and Projects
sub_topics.short_description: Writing comprehensive research-based papers developed over weeks.
example_tasks: Complete a 3-5 page research paper on a historical topic over three weeks, including research, drafting, and revision.
Write a multi-week science research report that includes hypothesis, methodology, results, and analysis.
Develop a literary analysis essay over two weeks, including multiple drafts with peer and teacher feedback.
Create a comprehensive informative essay on a complex topic using multiple sources and developed over several weeks.
Write an extended argumentative essay addressing a controversial issue with thorough research and multiple revisions.

sub_topics.name: Extended Creative Writing Projects
sub_topics.short_description: Developing substantial narrative or creative pieces over extended periods.
example_tasks: Write a short story or personal narrative of 1500+ words developed over two to three weeks.
Create a portfolio of related poems developed and revised over a month-long unit.
Write and revise a multi-chapter narrative piece over several weeks.
Develop a creative nonfiction piece (memoir, personal essay) with multiple drafts and revisions.
Complete a dramatic scene or one-act play developed over an extended time period.

sub_topics.name: Engaging in Substantive Revision
sub_topics.short_description: Producing multiple drafts with significant revision between them.
example_tasks: Complete at least three distinct drafts of an essay, making substantive changes beyond just correcting errors.
Revise a draft based on peer and teacher feedback, addressing content, organization, and style issues.
Track changes between drafts to see how your writing improves through the revision process.
Set aside a draft for several days, then return with fresh perspective to revise substantially.
Focus different revision sessions on different aspects: content, organization, style, then conventions.

sub_topics.name: Writing in Shorter Time Frames
sub_topics.short_description: Producing writing in single sittings or over a day or two for specific tasks.

sub_topics.name: Timed Writing and Responses
sub_topics.short_description: Writing focused responses within time constraints, such as during tests or class periods.
example_tasks: Write a literary analysis paragraph in response to a passage in 30 minutes.
Complete a one-page argumentative response to a prompt during a 45-minute class period.
Write a summary and response to an article within a single class period.
Answer an extended response question on a test with a well-developed paragraph in 20 minutes.
Write a quick reflective response to a text or discussion in 15 minutes.

sub_topics.name: Short Informative and Explanatory Writing
sub_topics.short_description: Writing brief explanations, summaries, or informative pieces in one or two sittings.
example_tasks: Write a one-page explanation of a scientific concept for homework, completed in one evening.
Create a summary of a chapter or article that captures main ideas in 1-2 paragraphs.
Write a brief informative email or letter explaining a process or providing information.
Compose a short comparison of two historical events or literary characters in one class period.
Write a quick-write response explaining your understanding of a new concept.

sub_topics.name: Daily Writing Practice and Journals
sub_topics.short_description: Writing regularly in journals, learning logs, or quick-writes to develop fluency.
example_tasks: Keep a reading journal with brief entries reflecting on daily reading.
Write daily quick-writes responding to prompts or reflecting on learning.
Maintain a writer's notebook with observations, ideas, and experimental writing.
Complete learning log entries that summarize and reflect on lessons.
Practice freewriting regularly to develop fluency and generate ideas.

sub_topics.name: On-Demand Writing for Various Purposes
sub_topics.short_description: Writing for immediate needs in academic and real-world contexts.
example_tasks: Write a persuasive email to a principal suggesting a school improvement in 20 minutes.
Draft a letter to the editor about a current issue in one sitting.
Write directions or instructions for completing a task clearly and concisely.
Compose a thank-you note or formal correspondence following appropriate conventions.
Write a brief proposal for a class project or activity in one class period.

sub_topics.name: Writing for a Range of Purposes and Audiences
sub_topics.short_description: Adapting writing approaches for different contexts, purposes, and intended readers.

sub_topics.name: Academic Writing Tasks
sub_topics.short_description: Writing for teachers and academic audiences across disciplines.
example_tasks: Write lab reports, science explanations, and research papers following disciplinary conventions.
Complete literary analyses and text-based responses for English class.
Write historical analyses and document-based essays for social studies.
Create mathematical explanations and problem-solving write-ups showing reasoning.
Write various academic essays (expository, analytical, argumentative) with appropriate formal style.

sub_topics.name: Personal and Reflective Writing
sub_topics.short_description: Writing about personal experiences, thoughts, and learning for authentic purposes.
example_tasks: Write personal narratives about meaningful experiences in your life.
Keep reflective journals about your learning, growth, and challenges.
Write memoir pieces that explore significant moments or relationships.
Create reflective essays about your reading experiences and responses to literature.
Write self-assessments that honestly evaluate your work and set goals for improvement.

sub_topics.name: Practical and Real-World Writing
sub_topics.short_description: Writing for authentic purposes outside of academic exercises.
example_tasks: Write business letters, emails, and formal correspondence following appropriate conventions.
Create instructions, directions, or how-to guides that others can follow.
Write persuasive letters to community members, officials, or publications.
Draft applications, cover letters, or proposals for real opportunities.
Create informative brochures, flyers, or presentations for authentic audiences.

sub_topics.name: Creative and Expressive Writing
sub_topics.short_description: Writing stories, poems, and other creative pieces for various audiences.
example_tasks: Write short stories in various genres for peers or wider audiences.
Create poetry using different forms and techniques to express ideas and emotions.
Write scripts or dramatic scenes that could be performed.
Develop creative nonfiction pieces that use literary techniques to tell true stories.
Write for publication in school literary magazines, online platforms, or contests.

name: Language - Conventions of Standard English
short_description: Students demonstrate command of grammar, usage, and mechanics when writing and speaking. They learn to apply standard English conventions appropriately and effectively in various contexts.

sub_topics.name: Grammar and Usage
sub_topics.short_description: Applying rules of standard English grammar and usage correctly in writing and speaking.

sub_topics.name: Pronoun Usage and Agreement
sub_topics.short_description: Using pronouns correctly with proper case, agreement, and clear antecedents.
example_tasks: Identify and correct pronoun case errors (I/me, who/whom, they/them) in sentences.
Ensure pronoun-antecedent agreement in number and gender throughout a paragraph.
Revise sentences to clarify vague pronoun references (ambiguous 'it,' 'this,' 'they').
Use intensive pronouns (myself, herself, themselves) correctly for emphasis.
Correct shifts in pronoun point of view (switching from 'you' to 'one' or from third to second person).

sub_topics.name: Verb Tense and Agreement
sub_topics.short_description: Using verb tenses consistently and ensuring subject-verb agreement.
example_tasks: Maintain consistent verb tense throughout a narrative or essay unless shifts are intentional.
Correct subject-verb agreement errors, especially with compound subjects and intervening phrases.
Use perfect tenses (present perfect, past perfect, future perfect) correctly to show time relationships.
Form and use progressive tenses correctly (am running, was reading, will be studying).
Recognize and correct inappropriate tense shifts within sentences and paragraphs.

sub_topics.name: Recognizing and Correcting Common Errors
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and fixing frequently occurring grammatical mistakes.
example_tasks: Identify and correct sentence fragments by adding subjects or predicates.
Fix run-on sentences and comma splices using appropriate punctuation or conjunctions.
Correct double negatives to express intended meaning clearly.
Identify and revise dangling or misplaced modifiers for clarity.
Correct faulty parallelism in lists or comparisons to improve sentence structure.

sub_topics.name: Using Phrases and Clauses
sub_topics.short_description: Employing various phrase and clause types to add variety and complexity to writing.
example_tasks: Identify and use different types of phrases (prepositional, appositive, participial, infinitive) in sentences.
Combine sentences using subordinate clauses to show relationships between ideas.
Distinguish between independent and dependent clauses in complex sentences.
Use relative clauses (who, which, that) correctly to add descriptive information.
Place phrases and clauses strategically to emphasize important information and vary sentence structure.

sub_topics.name: Using Adjectives and Adverbs Correctly
sub_topics.short_description: Choosing and placing modifiers appropriately to describe and enhance meaning.
example_tasks: Distinguish between adjectives and adverbs and use each correctly (good/well, bad/badly).
Use comparative and superlative forms correctly (better/best, more interesting/most interesting).
Avoid overuse of adverbs by choosing stronger, more precise verbs instead.
Place adjectives and adverbs to clearly modify the intended words.
Use articles (a, an, the) correctly in various contexts.

sub_topics.name: Punctuation and Capitalization
sub_topics.short_description: Using punctuation marks and capital letters correctly to clarify meaning and follow conventions.

sub_topics.name: End Punctuation
sub_topics.short_description: Using periods, question marks, and exclamation points appropriately.
example_tasks: Ensure all sentences end with appropriate punctuation marks.
Distinguish between statements, questions, and exclamations and punctuate accordingly.
Avoid overusing exclamation points in formal or academic writing.
Punctuate indirect questions correctly with periods rather than question marks.
Use question marks appropriately in sentences containing embedded questions.

sub_topics.name: Comma Usage
sub_topics.short_description: Using commas correctly in various grammatical situations.
example_tasks: Use commas to separate items in a series, including before the coordinating conjunction (Oxford comma).
Place commas correctly in compound sentences before coordinating conjunctions (and, but, or, so).
Use commas after introductory elements (phrases and clauses) at the beginning of sentences.
Set off nonessential clauses and phrases with commas (My brother, who lives in Texas, is visiting).
Use commas correctly with appositives, direct address, and interrupting elements.

sub_topics.name: Semicolons and Colons
sub_topics.short_description: Using semicolons and colons appropriately to connect ideas and introduce lists or explanations.
example_tasks: Use semicolons to join closely related independent clauses without a conjunction.
Use semicolons to separate items in a series when items contain internal commas.
Use colons to introduce lists, explanations, or quotations following independent clauses.
Distinguish between situations requiring semicolons versus colons.
Avoid common errors like placing colons after verbs or prepositions.

sub_topics.name: Quotation Marks and Dialogue Punctuation
sub_topics.short_description: Punctuating direct quotations and dialogue correctly.
example_tasks: Punctuate direct quotations correctly with commas, periods, and other marks inside quotation marks.
Format dialogue in narratives with proper paragraphing and punctuation.
Use quotation marks correctly for titles of short works (poems, articles, short stories).
Distinguish between direct quotations requiring quotation marks and indirect quotations that don't.
Place other punctuation marks (semicolons, colons, question marks) correctly in relation to quotation marks.

sub_topics.name: Apostrophes, Hyphens, and Dashes
sub_topics.short_description: Using apostrophes, hyphens, and dashes correctly for various purposes.
example_tasks: Use apostrophes correctly to form possessives (singular and plural nouns).
Use apostrophes correctly in contractions to show omitted letters.
Use hyphens correctly in compound adjectives (well-known author) and numbers.
Use em dashes to set off additional information or create emphasis.
Avoid confusing its/it's, your/you're, and their/they're/there.

sub_topics.name: Capitalization Rules
sub_topics.short_description: Applying capitalization rules correctly for various words and contexts.
example_tasks: Capitalize proper nouns (names of specific people, places, organizations) correctly.
Capitalize titles of people when used with names but not when used generally.
Capitalize the first word of sentences and direct quotations.
Capitalize titles of works correctly, following standard rules for major and minor words.
Recognize when to capitalize words like 'north,' 'mother,' or 'school' based on context.

sub_topics.name: Spelling Conventions
sub_topics.short_description: Applying spelling rules and using resources to spell words correctly.

sub_topics.name: Applying Spelling Patterns and Rules
sub_topics.short_description: Using knowledge of spelling patterns to spell words correctly.
example_tasks: Apply the rule for adding suffixes to words ending in 'e' (hope/hoping, care/careful).
Use the 'i before e except after c' rule and know its exceptions.
Apply rules for doubling consonants when adding suffixes (run/running, big/bigger).
Spell words with common prefixes and suffixes correctly (un-, re-, -tion, -ness).
Recognize and spell homophones correctly based on context (their/there/they're, to/too/two).

sub_topics.name: Distinguishing Commonly Confused Words
sub_topics.short_description: Correctly using words that are often confused due to similar spelling or pronunciation.
example_tasks: Choose correctly between affect/effect, accept/except, principle/principal in sentences.
Use lie/lay, sit/set, and rise/raise correctly based on whether objects are involved.
Distinguish between then/than, lose/loose, and quiet/quite in writing.
Use further/farther and fewer/less correctly based on context.
Correctly choose between complement/compliment, counsel/council, and dessert/desert.

sub_topics.name: Using Spelling Resources
sub_topics.short_description: Employing dictionaries, spell-check, and other tools to verify correct spelling.
example_tasks: Use a dictionary to check spelling and verify word choice when uncertain.
Use spell-check as a first step but recognize its limitations with homophones.
Consult style guides for spelling of technical or specialized terms.
Keep a personal list of words you commonly misspell and study them.
Verify spelling of proper nouns and specialized vocabulary through reliable sources.

name: Language - Knowledge of Language
short_description: Students make effective language choices regarding style, register, and vocabulary. They understand how language functions in different contexts and how to adapt their expression for various purposes and audiences.

sub_topics.name: Choosing Language for Effect
sub_topics.short_description: Selecting words and phrases strategically to achieve desired effects on readers or listeners.

sub_topics.name: Varying Syntax for Effect
sub_topics.short_description: Manipulating sentence structure to control emphasis, rhythm, and reader engagement.
example_tasks: Rewrite a passage using varied sentence lengths to create different effects (tension vs. calm).
Combine short sentences to create complexity or break long sentences to add emphasis.
Experiment with different sentence openings to avoid monotonous patterns.
Use periodic sentences (main idea at end) to build suspense or emphasis.
Analyze how sentence structure affects the pace and mood of a piece of writing.

sub_topics.name: Choosing Words for Precision and Tone
sub_topics.short_description: Selecting specific words that convey exact meaning and appropriate tone.
example_tasks: Replace general verbs (went, said, got) with more precise alternatives (trudged, whispered, acquired).
Choose words with connotations that support your intended tone (cheap vs. economical vs. inexpensive).
Revise writing to eliminate vague words (thing, stuff, very, really) with specific alternatives.
Select vocabulary that matches the formality level appropriate for your audience and purpose.
Compare word choices in professional writing versus casual communication and explain the differences.

sub_topics.name: Maintaining Consistency in Style and Tone
sub_topics.short_description: Ensuring consistent approach to language throughout a piece of writing.
example_tasks: Maintain consistent level of formality throughout an essay (avoid mixing slang with academic language).
Ensure consistent point of view throughout a narrative (don't shift from first to third person).
Keep verb tense consistent unless shifts are intentionally used for effect.
Maintain consistent tone (serious, humorous, objective) appropriate to purpose.
Identify and revise inconsistencies in style that distract or confuse readers.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Formal and Informal English
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing different registers of language and when each is appropriate.

sub_topics.name: Using Formal English Appropriately
sub_topics.short_description: Employing formal language in academic and professional contexts.
example_tasks: Rewrite informal sentences in formal academic style for a research paper.
Identify informal language in a draft (contractions, slang, colloquialisms) and revise to formal style.
Write a formal letter or email using appropriate conventions and tone.
Explain when formal language is expected (essays, presentations, professional communication).
Compare the same message written in formal versus informal style and identify specific differences.

sub_topics.name: Using Informal English Appropriately
sub_topics.short_description: Employing informal language effectively in personal and creative contexts.
example_tasks: Write realistic dialogue for characters using informal, conversational language.
Create a personal narrative that uses informal language appropriately to establish voice.
Distinguish between contexts where informal language is acceptable versus inappropriate.
Use contractions, casual vocabulary, and conversational tone in informal writing.
Explain how informal language can create authenticity in certain types of writing (personal essays, creative nonfiction).

sub_topics.name: Adapting Language for Different Contexts
sub_topics.short_description: Adjusting language register based on audience, purpose, and situation.
example_tasks: Rewrite the same message for three different audiences (teacher, friend, principal) with appropriate register for each.
Explain how you would adjust your language when speaking to different audiences (peers vs. adults).
Identify which register is appropriate for different writing tasks (thank-you note, lab report, text message).
Practice switching between formal and informal language based on context.
Analyze examples of professional writing that use different levels of formality for different audiences.

sub_topics.name: Consulting Reference Materials
sub_topics.short_description: Using dictionaries, style guides, and other resources to make informed language choices.

sub_topics.name: Using Dictionaries and Thesauruses
sub_topics.short_description: Consulting reference materials to verify meanings, spellings, and find alternatives.
example_tasks: Look up a word in the dictionary to check pronunciation, part of speech, and multiple meanings.
Use a thesaurus to find synonyms but verify meanings before substituting words.
Use dictionary pronunciation guides and etymology information to understand word origins.
Compare definitions from multiple dictionaries when encountering subtle differences in meaning.
Use digital dictionaries effectively, understanding how to interpret abbreviations and usage labels.

sub_topics.name: Using Style Guides and Grammar Resources
sub_topics.short_description: Consulting authoritative sources for grammar, usage, and formatting questions.
example_tasks: Use a grammar handbook to look up rules for punctuation or grammar questions.
Consult MLA or APA style guides for formatting questions in research papers.
Use reliable online resources (Purdue OWL, Grammarly Handbook) to answer usage questions.
Check style guides to determine correct capitalization, italicization, or formatting of titles.
Develop the habit of consulting references rather than guessing when uncertain about conventions.

name: Language - Vocabulary Acquisition and Use
short_description: Students determine word meanings, understand figurative language, analyze word relationships, and acquire academic and domain-specific vocabulary. They develop strategies for independent vocabulary learning.

sub_topics.name: Using Context Clues
sub_topics.short_description: Determining word meanings by analyzing surrounding text and situational context.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Types of Context Clues
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing different ways context provides clues to word meaning.
example_tasks: Identify definition clues where the text directly defines an unfamiliar word.
Find example clues where the text provides examples that illustrate the word's meaning.
Recognize contrast clues where the text shows what the word does NOT mean.
Use inference clues by piecing together meaning from general context.
Identify synonym or restatement clues where the text uses a familiar word with similar meaning.

sub_topics.name: Using Context to Determine Meaning
sub_topics.short_description: Applying context clue strategies to figure out unfamiliar words while reading.
example_tasks: Read a passage with unfamiliar words and use context to determine their meanings before checking a dictionary.
Explain how you used specific context clues to figure out the meaning of a challenging word.
Determine which meaning of a multiple-meaning word fits the context of a particular sentence.
Use context to distinguish between similar words (imply vs. infer, empathy vs. sympathy).
Practice reading increasingly complex texts and using context to understand new vocabulary independently.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Word Parts
sub_topics.short_description: Using knowledge of roots, prefixes, and suffixes to determine meanings of unfamiliar words.

sub_topics.name: Using Prefixes and Suffixes
sub_topics.short_description: Applying knowledge of common affixes to decode word meanings.
example_tasks: Identify how prefixes like un-, re-, pre-, mis- change the meaning of base words.
Determine how suffixes like -tion, -ity, -ness, -ment change words from one part of speech to another.
Break down complex words into prefix + root + suffix and determine meaning from parts.
Learn common negative prefixes (un-, in-, dis-, non-) and how they negate meaning.
Use knowledge of comparative and superlative suffixes (-er, -est, more, most) to understand word relationships.

sub_topics.name: Using Greek and Latin Roots
sub_topics.short_description: Applying knowledge of common root words to understand related vocabulary.
example_tasks: Identify the root 'scrib/script' (write) in words like describe, prescription, manuscript.
Learn common roots like port (carry), dict (speak), ject (throw) and find words containing them.
Use knowledge of Greek roots like bio (life), geo (earth), photo (light) to understand scientific terms.
Recognize word families that share the same root (spectator, spectacle, inspection, respect).
Create word webs showing how one root connects multiple related words.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Etymology and Word Origins
sub_topics.short_description: Using knowledge of word origins to understand and remember vocabulary.
example_tasks: Use dictionary etymology information to understand how a word's origin relates to its current meaning.
Explain how knowing that 'biography' comes from Greek 'bio' (life) + 'graphy' (writing) helps understand related words.
Trace how words borrowed from other languages (Spanish, French, German) retain elements of their origins.
Understand how some words' meanings have evolved from their original meanings over time.
Use knowledge of word origins to remember and distinguish between similar words.

sub_topics.name: Interpreting Figurative Language
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and analyzing nonliteral language including figures of speech and word relationships.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Similes and Metaphors
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and interpreting comparisons that create imagery and meaning.
example_tasks: Identify similes (using 'like' or 'as') in a text and explain what is being compared.
Identify metaphors (direct comparisons without 'like' or 'as') and explain their meaning.
Explain what a metaphor reveals that a literal statement would not (e.g., 'time is money').
Create your own similes and metaphors to describe abstract concepts or experiences.
Analyze extended metaphors in poetry or literature and trace the comparison throughout the text.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Personification and Hyperbole
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing when nonhuman things are given human qualities or when exaggeration is used for effect.
example_tasks: Identify personification in texts where nonhuman things are described with human characteristics.
Explain the effect of personification in creating mood or emphasizing ideas.
Identify hyperbole (extreme exaggeration) and explain its purpose in the text.
Distinguish between literal statements and hyperbole in various contexts.
Create examples of personification and hyperbole appropriate for different purposes.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Idioms and Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting common expressions whose meanings differ from their literal words.
example_tasks: Identify idioms in text (e.g., 'break the ice,' 'piece of cake') and explain their figurative meanings.
Explain why idioms can be confusing to non-native speakers or those unfamiliar with them.
Determine the meaning of unfamiliar idioms using context clues.
Distinguish between idioms and literal language in various texts.
Understand that idioms are culturally specific and may not translate directly to other languages.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Symbolism and Allusion
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing when objects represent abstract ideas and when texts reference other works or events.
example_tasks: Identify symbols in literature (e.g., a dove representing peace) and explain their meaning in context.
Recognize allusions to historical events, mythology, or other literary works in texts.
Explain how understanding an allusion enriches the meaning of a text.
Interpret what abstract concepts or themes symbols represent in specific texts.
Create your own symbols to represent complex ideas in creative writing.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Connotation and Denotation
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between literal meanings and emotional associations of words.
example_tasks: Distinguish between the denotation (dictionary definition) and connotation (emotional association) of words.
Explain how words like 'childlike' and 'childish' have similar denotations but different connotations.
Analyze how an author's word choice creates positive, negative, or neutral connotations.
Choose synonyms with appropriate connotations for different contexts and purposes.
Explain how connotation affects tone and reader response in specific passages.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Word Relationships
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how words relate to each other through synonyms, antonyms, analogies, and other connections.

sub_topics.name: Using Synonyms and Antonyms
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding words with similar and opposite meanings.
example_tasks: Identify synonyms for overused words to add variety to writing (happy: joyful, content, elated).
Distinguish between near-synonyms that have subtle differences in meaning or connotation.
Identify antonyms and explain how they create contrast in writing.
Use synonym and antonym relationships to understand new vocabulary.
Choose the most precise synonym from several options based on context and connotation.

sub_topics.name: Understanding and Completing Analogies
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing relationships between word pairs and applying them to new situations.
example_tasks: Complete analogies showing part-to-whole relationships (wheel : car :: page : book).
Complete analogies showing cause-and-effect relationships (practice : improvement :: study : knowledge).
Complete analogies showing synonym or antonym relationships.
Explain the type of relationship shown in a given analogy.
Create your own analogies to demonstrate understanding of word relationships.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Word Categories and Hierarchies
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing how words fit into categories and levels of specificity.
example_tasks: Arrange words from general to specific (vehicle  car  sedan  Honda Accord).
Identify which words belong to the same category and which do not.
Understand relationships between broader terms and specific examples (fruit: apple, banana, orange).
Use category words to organize vocabulary and understand relationships.
Create word maps showing hierarchical relationships among related terms.

sub_topics.name: Acquiring Academic and Domain-Specific Vocabulary
sub_topics.short_description: Learning and using specialized vocabulary for different academic subjects and contexts.

sub_topics.name: Learning General Academic Vocabulary
sub_topics.short_description: Acquiring vocabulary commonly used across academic disciplines.
example_tasks: Learn and use academic words like analyze, evaluate, synthesize, infer, and justify in discussions and writing.
Understand transition words and phrases used in academic writing (furthermore, consequently, nevertheless).
Use precise academic verbs instead of general ones (examine rather than look at, demonstrate rather than show).
Build vocabulary related to thinking and learning (hypothesis, evidence, conclusion, perspective).
Practice using academic vocabulary in written and spoken responses across subjects.

sub_topics.name: Learning Subject-Specific Vocabulary
sub_topics.short_description: Acquiring specialized terminology for different academic disciplines.
example_tasks: Learn and use literary terms (theme, characterization, foreshadowing, symbolism, irony).
Build vocabulary specific to science (hypothesis, variable, organism, ecosystem, photosynthesis).
Learn historical and social studies terms (democracy, revolution, migration, imperialism).
Acquire mathematical vocabulary (equation, coefficient, proportion, variable, theorem).
Create subject-specific vocabulary journals or glossaries to track new terms.

sub_topics.name: Using New Vocabulary in Context
sub_topics.short_description: Incorporating learned vocabulary into speaking and writing appropriately.
example_tasks: Use newly learned vocabulary words correctly in original sentences showing their meaning.
Incorporate domain-specific terms in subject-area writing and discussions.
Practice using academic vocabulary in formal presentations and essays.
Avoid overusing sophisticated vocabulary when simpler words communicate more clearly.
Demonstrate understanding of new words by using them accurately in varied contexts.

sub_topics.name: Developing Independent Vocabulary Learning Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Building habits and strategies for continuous vocabulary acquisition.
example_tasks: Keep a vocabulary notebook or digital list of new words encountered in reading with definitions and examples.
Set personal goals for learning a certain number of new words per week.
Use new vocabulary words in conversation and writing to reinforce learning.
Create flashcards, word maps, or other study tools for vocabulary review.
Practice reading widely to encounter diverse vocabulary in various contexts.

name: Poetry Analysis and Forms
short_description: Students analyze poetic techniques, interpret meaning in poetry, and understand various poetic forms and structures. They explore how poets use language, sound devices, and structure to create meaning and emotional effect.

sub_topics.name: Poetic Devices and Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and analyzing literary devices specific to poetry.

sub_topics.name: Sound Devices in Poetry
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how poets use sound to create musical effects and enhance meaning.
example_tasks: Identify examples of alliteration (repetition of initial consonant sounds) in a poem and explain their effect.
Find assonance (repetition of vowel sounds) and consonance (repetition of consonant sounds) in a poem.
Analyze how onomatopoeia (words that imitate sounds) contributes to imagery in a poem.
Identify rhyme scheme in a poem using letter notation (ABAB, AABB, etc.).
Explain how sound devices like repetition create rhythm, emphasis, or mood in a specific poem.

sub_topics.name: Imagery and Sensory Language
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how poets create vivid mental pictures through descriptive language.
example_tasks: Identify imagery that appeals to different senses (visual, auditory, tactile, olfactory, gustatory) in a poem.
Explain how specific images contribute to the overall mood or theme of a poem.
Analyze how concrete images represent abstract ideas in a poem.
Compare how two poets use different imagery to describe similar subjects.
Create a visualization or illustration based on the imagery in a poem.

sub_topics.name: Figurative Language in Poetry
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting metaphors, similes, personification, and other figures of speech in poems.
example_tasks: Identify and interpret extended metaphors that run throughout a poem.
Analyze how personification brings abstract concepts or inanimate objects to life in poetry.
Explain what a particular simile or metaphor reveals that literal language would not.
Identify symbolism in a poem and explain what objects or images represent.
Trace how a poet develops a central image or comparison throughout a poem.

sub_topics.name: Poetic Structure and Form
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how poets organize language through line breaks, stanzas, and traditional forms.

sub_topics.name: Lines, Line Breaks, and Stanzas
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how poets use line and stanza structure to create meaning and emphasis.
example_tasks: Explain how a poet's choice of where to break lines affects emphasis and pacing.
Analyze the effect of enjambment (lines that run on without punctuation) versus end-stopped lines.
Describe how stanza breaks create pauses or shifts in thought or mood.
Compare the effect of short versus long lines in conveying different emotions or pacing.
Rewrite a poem with different line breaks and explain how it changes the reading experience.

sub_topics.name: Traditional Poetic Forms
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing and understanding characteristics of structured poetic forms.
example_tasks: Identify the characteristics of a sonnet (14 lines, specific rhyme scheme) and analyze an example.
Recognize haiku structure (three lines, 5-7-5 syllable pattern) and its focus on nature and moments.
Identify free verse poetry and explain how it differs from formal poetry with set patterns.
Analyze a ballad and identify its narrative elements and regular rhythm and rhyme.
Compare limerick structure (AABBA rhyme, humorous tone) with more serious poetic forms.

sub_topics.name: Rhythm and Meter
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding patterns of stressed and unstressed syllables in poetry.
example_tasks: Identify regular rhythm patterns in poems by marking stressed and unstressed syllables.
Recognize common meters like iambic (unstressed-stressed) in simple poems.
Explain how regular rhythm creates a musical quality or predictable pattern in poetry.
Identify where a poet breaks from regular rhythm for emphasis or effect.
Compare the rhythm of a formal poem with regular meter to free verse with irregular rhythm.

sub_topics.name: Repetition and Refrain
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how poets use repeated words, phrases, or lines for emphasis.
example_tasks: Identify repeated words or phrases in a poem and explain their effect on meaning or emotion.
Analyze how a refrain (repeated line or stanza) reinforces the theme or creates unity.
Explain how repetition creates emphasis, rhythm, or builds intensity in a poem.
Compare how different poets use repetition to achieve different effects.
Identify parallel structure (repeated grammatical patterns) and its effect in poetry.

sub_topics.name: Interpreting Meaning in Poetry
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing poems to understand theme, tone, speaker, and deeper meanings.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Theme in Poetry
sub_topics.short_description: Determining the central message or insight about life that a poem conveys.
example_tasks: Identify the theme of a poem by analyzing key images, repeated ideas, and the overall message.
Distinguish between the subject (what the poem is about) and the theme (what it says about the subject).
Explain how specific poetic devices and images develop the theme throughout the poem.
Compare how two poems explore similar themes in different ways.
Support your interpretation of theme with specific evidence from the poem's language and structure.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Tone and Mood
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying the speaker's attitude and the emotional atmosphere of a poem.
example_tasks: Identify the tone (speaker's attitude) in a poem by analyzing word choice and imagery.
Distinguish between tone (poet's attitude) and mood (reader's emotional response).
Explain how sound devices, rhythm, and word choice create a particular mood.
Trace how tone shifts during a poem and what causes those shifts.
Compare the tones of two poems on similar subjects and explain the differences.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Speaker and Point of View
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying who is speaking in the poem and their perspective.
example_tasks: Distinguish between the poet and the speaker of a poem (they may not be the same).
Describe the speaker's perspective, situation, and attitude based on evidence in the poem.
Identify whether the speaker is addressing someone specific or speaking generally.
Analyze how the speaker's point of view affects the reader's understanding of the poem.
Explain what the speaker reveals about themselves through their observations and language.

sub_topics.name: Close Reading and Analysis of Poetry
sub_topics.short_description: Examining poems carefully to understand how all elements work together to create meaning.
example_tasks: Perform a close reading by analyzing each stanza's contribution to overall meaning.
Explain how multiple poetic devices work together in a single poem to create a unified effect.
Analyze how the form and structure of a poem relate to its content and meaning.
Support an interpretation with specific quotations and analysis of language and technique.
Write an analytical paragraph explaining how a poet uses specific techniques to convey theme.

sub_topics.name: Comparing and Contrasting Poems
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing similarities and differences between poems in terms of themes, techniques, and forms.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Themes and Approaches
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how different poets treat similar subjects or themes.
example_tasks: Compare how two poems approach the same theme (nature, love, loss) with different perspectives.
Analyze how two poets use different tones to convey similar messages.
Compare traditional and contemporary poems on the same subject and explain how approaches differ.
Identify which poem's approach to a theme you find more effective and explain why with evidence.
Create a comparison chart showing how two poems differ in theme, tone, form, and technique.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Techniques and Styles
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how different poets use poetic devices and structural elements differently.
example_tasks: Compare how two poets use imagery differently (sparse vs. rich, concrete vs. abstract).
Analyze differences in form between a structured poem (sonnet) and free verse on the same theme.
Compare how two poets use sound devices to create different effects.
Explain how two poets' different styles (simple language vs. complex, formal vs. conversational) suit their purposes.
Compare the pacing and rhythm of two poems and how it affects their emotional impact.

name: Drama and Theater
short_description: Students analyze dramatic texts and performances, understanding how plays use dialogue, action, staging, and dramatic elements to convey meaning. They explore how drama differs from other literary forms.

sub_topics.name: Dramatic Structure and Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the components and organization of dramatic texts.

sub_topics.name: Acts, Scenes, and Dramatic Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how plays are organized into acts and scenes with specific structural purposes.
example_tasks: Identify the five-act structure in a traditional play and explain what happens in each act.
Analyze how a scene break creates a shift in time, place, or focus in a play.
Explain how the climax and resolution function differently in drama than in prose fiction.
Compare the pacing created by many short scenes versus fewer long scenes in a play.
Identify where the exposition, rising action, climax, and falling action occur in a play you've read.

sub_topics.name: Stage Directions and Setting
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how playwrights convey information about action, setting, and staging through directions.
example_tasks: Analyze stage directions to understand how characters move and interact on stage.
Explain how stage directions about lighting or sound create mood or emphasize important moments.
Visualize the physical setting of a scene based on the playwright's descriptions.
Compare how much information different playwrights provide in stage directions.
Explain how minimalist or detailed stage directions affect how a play might be interpreted and performed.

sub_topics.name: Dramatic Conventions
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing special techniques used in drama like soliloquy, aside, and monologue.
example_tasks: Identify soliloquies where characters speak their thoughts aloud when alone on stage.
Recognize asides where characters speak to the audience without other characters hearing.
Distinguish between monologues (long speeches to other characters) and soliloquies (speaking alone).
Explain how soliloquies and asides reveal characters' true thoughts and feelings.
Analyze what important information is conveyed through dramatic conventions that couldn't be shown through action alone.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Dialogue
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how playwrights develop character and advance plot through spoken words.

sub_topics.name: Characterization Through Dialogue
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how characters are revealed through their speech patterns and word choices.
example_tasks: Analyze how a character's vocabulary, tone, and speech patterns reveal their personality and background.
Compare how two characters speak differently and what this reveals about their relationship or status.
Identify how a character's way of speaking changes in different situations or with different characters.
Explain how dialect, slang, or formal language characterizes different individuals in a play.
Analyze what a character reveals about themselves through both what they say and how they say it.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Subtext in Dialogue
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing when characters mean something different from what they literally say.
example_tasks: Identify instances where a character's words say one thing but their meaning is something else.
Analyze dialogue where characters are being sarcastic, evasive, or deliberately misleading.
Explain what unspoken tensions or emotions lie beneath polite or formal dialogue.
Identify dramatic irony where the audience understands more than the characters do.
Analyze how stage directions about tone or body language reveal subtext in dialogue.

sub_topics.name: Conflict and Tension in Dialogue
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how disagreements and conflicts unfold through character interactions.
example_tasks: Identify how dialogue reveals conflicts between characters' goals, values, or desires.
Analyze how the pace and intensity of dialogue exchanges build dramatic tension.
Trace how an argument develops through dialogue, escalating toward a crisis point.
Explain how interruptions, short exchanges, or overlapping speech create urgency or conflict.
Analyze a heated exchange and identify the underlying issue beyond what's explicitly discussed.

sub_topics.name: Dramatic Techniques and Effects
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how playwrights use specific techniques to create meaning and engage audiences.

sub_topics.name: Foreshadowing and Dramatic Irony
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how playwrights hint at future events and create tension through audience knowledge.
example_tasks: Identify instances of foreshadowing where dialogue or events hint at what will happen later.
Explain how dramatic irony occurs when the audience knows something characters don't.
Analyze how foreshadowing creates suspense and prepares the audience for later developments.
Identify moments where a character's words take on additional meaning because of dramatic irony.
Explain how dramatic irony affects audience engagement and emotional response to events.

sub_topics.name: Symbolism in Drama
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing how objects, actions, or settings represent larger ideas in plays.
example_tasks: Identify symbolic objects in a play and explain what they represent (e.g., a light, a photograph, a piece of clothing).
Analyze how a symbolic action or gesture reveals character or theme.
Explain how the setting itself might be symbolic of characters' situations or the play's themes.
Trace how a symbol's meaning develops or changes throughout the play.
Compare how different characters relate to or interpret the same symbolic element.

sub_topics.name: Humor and Comedy Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how playwrights create comic effects through various devices.
example_tasks: Identify verbal humor in dialogue (puns, wordplay, witty exchanges, exaggeration).
Recognize situational comedy based on misunderstandings, mistaken identity, or unlikely coincidences.
Analyze physical comedy suggested in stage directions (slapstick, pratfalls, comic business).
Explain how comedy can serve serious purposes by highlighting social issues or human foibles.
Compare how different characters provide comic relief in a serious or tragic play.

sub_topics.name: Staging and Performance Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how drama is designed for performance and how staging choices affect meaning.

sub_topics.name: Visualizing Performance
sub_topics.short_description: Imagining how a play would look and sound when performed on stage.
example_tasks: Describe how you would stage a particular scene, including set, blocking, and character positioning.
Explain what costumes would be appropriate for characters based on the text and time period.
Visualize how lighting could be used to create mood or focus attention in specific scenes.
Imagine how actors might deliver lines based on context, character, and dramatic situation.
Sketch a simple set design for a scene based on the playwright's descriptions and the play's needs.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Text to Performance
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing differences between reading a play and seeing it performed.
example_tasks: Compare how you imagined a scene while reading with how it was performed in a video or live production.
Analyze how actors' choices (tone, gestures, pacing) add interpretation beyond the written text.
Explain what a performance reveals about characters or relationships that isn't obvious in the text alone.
Evaluate whether a director's staging choices effectively convey the playwright's intentions.
Discuss how different actors or productions might interpret the same scene differently.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Performance Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how technical and artistic elements contribute to theatrical meaning.
example_tasks: Analyze how costume choices communicate information about character, time period, or status.
Explain how set design creates the world of the play and supports the action and themes.
Describe how lighting and sound effects create atmosphere or emphasize dramatic moments.
Evaluate how an actor's vocal choices (volume, pace, tone) affect the interpretation of a character.
Analyze how music underscores emotional moments or transitions between scenes in a performance.

sub_topics.name: Dramatic Genres and Forms
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different types of drama and their distinguishing characteristics.

sub_topics.name: Tragedy and Tragic Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing the conventions and purposes of tragic drama.
example_tasks: Identify characteristics of tragedy: a protagonist with a tragic flaw, serious tone, unhappy ending.
Analyze how a tragic hero's flaw or error in judgment leads to their downfall.
Explain how tragedy creates catharsis (emotional release) for the audience.
Identify the moment of recognition or reversal in a tragic play.
Compare classical tragedy conventions with modern tragic plays.

sub_topics.name: Comedy and Comic Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the features and purposes of comic drama.
example_tasks: Identify characteristics of comedy: humorous situations, happy endings, social commentary.
Analyze how comedies often resolve with marriages, reunions, or restored social order.
Explain how comedy can critique society or human behavior while entertaining.
Distinguish between different types of comedy (romantic, satirical, farcical).
Analyze how comedies often feature disguise, mistaken identity, or misunderstanding as plot devices.

name: Speaking and Listening - Comprehension and Collaboration
short_description: Students engage effectively in collaborative discussions, analyze diverse media and formats, and evaluate speakers' arguments and reasoning. They develop skills in active listening, respectful dialogue, and critical evaluation of oral presentations.

sub_topics.name: Engaging in Collaborative Discussions
sub_topics.short_description: Participating effectively in one-on-one, group, and teacher-led discussions on various topics and texts.

sub_topics.name: Preparing for Discussions
sub_topics.short_description: Coming to discussions ready with evidence and ideas from reading or research.
example_tasks: Read assigned texts and annotate key passages to reference during class discussion.
Prepare at least three discussion questions or comments based on your reading before a literature circle.
Gather evidence from multiple sources to support your position before a debate or discussion.
Review your notes and identify main ideas you want to contribute to the discussion.
Prepare specific quotations or examples from texts that you can cite during discussion.

sub_topics.name: Building on Others' Ideas
sub_topics.short_description: Listening to others and responding by elaborating, clarifying, or extending their contributions.
example_tasks: Listen to a peer's comment and respond by adding a related example or additional evidence.
Build on another student's interpretation by explaining how your ideas connect to or extend theirs.
Ask follow-up questions that help a peer develop or clarify their thinking.
Reference a classmate's earlier point and explain how new evidence supports or challenges it.
Synthesize multiple classmates' ideas to show connections or patterns in the discussion.

sub_topics.name: Expressing Ideas Clearly
sub_topics.short_description: Articulating thoughts, ideas, and evidence clearly in discussions.
example_tasks: State your interpretation of a text clearly and support it with specific evidence.
Explain your reasoning when you disagree with another person's point.
Contribute a new perspective or idea that hasn't been discussed yet.
Ask clarifying questions when you don't understand another person's point.
Summarize complex ideas in your own words to ensure understanding.

sub_topics.name: Following Discussion Roles and Norms
sub_topics.short_description: Tracking progress toward goals, following agreed-upon rules, and fulfilling assigned roles.
example_tasks: Serve as discussion leader by keeping the group on topic and ensuring everyone participates.
Take on the role of note-taker and record main ideas and decisions from the discussion.
Monitor time and help the group stay on schedule to address all discussion questions.
Follow norms like speaking one at a time, listening actively, and disagreeing respectfully.
Help redirect the discussion when it goes off-topic or ensure quieter members have opportunities to contribute.

sub_topics.name: Engaging with Diverse Perspectives
sub_topics.short_description: Considering multiple viewpoints and responding thoughtfully to different ideas and interpretations.
example_tasks: Listen to perspectives that differ from your own and consider their merits before responding.
Acknowledge the validity of another viewpoint even when you disagree with it.
Ask questions to better understand why someone holds a different interpretation or opinion.
Identify common ground between differing perspectives in a discussion.
Revise or refine your thinking based on compelling evidence or reasoning from others.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Information from Diverse Media
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting information presented in diverse formats and media, and evaluating its usefulness.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Visual and Multimedia Presentations
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting information from videos, graphics, audio, and digital sources.
example_tasks: Analyze a video documentary and identify its main claims and supporting evidence.
Evaluate how graphics, charts, or animations in a presentation clarify or enhance information.
Compare information gained from watching a video with information from reading a text on the same topic.
Analyze how music, narration, and visuals work together in a multimedia presentation to convey a message.
Identify bias or persuasive techniques in a video presentation or advertisement.

sub_topics.name: Integrating Visual and Oral Information
sub_topics.short_description: Combining information from multiple formats to develop comprehensive understanding.
example_tasks: Take notes on a speech or presentation and integrate them with information from written sources.
Use information from both a video and a text to write a comprehensive summary of a topic.
Compare how the same information is presented differently in oral, visual, and written formats.
Synthesize information from a panel discussion or multiple speakers on the same topic.
Evaluate which format (text, video, audio, graphics) presents information most effectively for a given purpose.

sub_topics.name: Evaluating Media Sources
sub_topics.short_description: Assessing the credibility and usefulness of information from various media.
example_tasks: Evaluate the credibility of a video source by examining the creator, publication date, and purpose.
Identify potential bias in a multimedia presentation based on what information is included or emphasized.
Compare how different news outlets present the same event in video or audio reports.
Assess whether a video or audio source provides sufficient evidence to support its claims.
Determine whether information from a podcast or video is relevant and appropriate for your research needs.

sub_topics.name: Evaluating a Speaker's Argument and Reasoning
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing and critiquing the claims, reasoning, evidence, and rhetoric in oral presentations.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Claims and Evidence in Oral Arguments
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing the main argument and supporting evidence in speeches and presentations.
example_tasks: Identify the main claim in a persuasive speech and state it in your own words.
List the types of evidence (facts, statistics, examples, expert opinions) a speaker uses to support their argument.
Distinguish between the speaker's opinions and factual evidence they provide.
Identify when a speaker makes unsupported claims without providing evidence.
Take organized notes that separate the speaker's claims from their supporting evidence.

sub_topics.name: Evaluating Reasoning and Logic
sub_topics.short_description: Assessing whether a speaker's reasoning is sound and conclusions are warranted.
example_tasks: Evaluate whether a speaker's conclusion logically follows from the evidence presented.
Identify logical fallacies in a speaker's argument (hasty generalization, false cause, ad hominem).
Assess whether a speaker's examples are representative or if they cherry-pick evidence.
Determine whether a speaker makes unwarranted assumptions or leaps in logic.
Explain whether a speaker adequately addresses potential counterarguments or objections.

sub_topics.name: Assessing Relevance and Sufficiency of Evidence
sub_topics.short_description: Evaluating whether evidence is relevant to claims and sufficient to support them.
example_tasks: Identify evidence in a speech that doesn't directly support the claim it's meant to support.
Evaluate whether a speaker provides enough evidence to make their argument convincing.
Determine whether a speaker's evidence is current and from credible sources.
Assess whether anecdotal evidence is appropriate or if more substantial evidence is needed.
Identify what additional evidence would strengthen a speaker's argument.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Rhetorical Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing and evaluating persuasive techniques speakers use to influence audiences.
example_tasks: Identify when a speaker uses emotional appeals (pathos) to persuade the audience.
Recognize when a speaker establishes credibility (ethos) through expertise or character.
Identify logical appeals (logos) based on facts, statistics, and reasoning.
Analyze how a speaker uses rhetorical questions, repetition, or parallel structure for effect.
Evaluate whether a speaker's persuasive techniques enhance or distract from the substance of their argument.

sub_topics.name: Recognizing Bias and Perspective
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying a speaker's point of view and potential biases that affect their presentation.
example_tasks: Identify a speaker's perspective on an issue and what biases might influence their presentation.
Recognize loaded language or word choices that reveal a speaker's bias.
Analyze what information a speaker includes or omits and how this reveals their perspective.
Evaluate whether a speaker presents opposing viewpoints fairly or dismisses them.
Consider how a speaker's background or affiliation might influence their argument.

name: Speaking and Listening - Presentation of Knowledge and Ideas
short_description: Students present information, findings, and supporting evidence clearly and logically. They adapt speech to various contexts and tasks, use digital media strategically, and demonstrate command of formal English when appropriate.

sub_topics.name: Presenting Claims and Findings
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing and delivering presentations with clear claims, logical sequences, and relevant evidence.

sub_topics.name: Organizing Content Logically
sub_topics.short_description: Structuring presentations with clear introductions, body, and conclusions.
example_tasks: Create an outline for a presentation that includes an engaging introduction, organized main points, and strong conclusion.
Organize information using an appropriate pattern (chronological, problem-solution, cause-effect) for your topic.
Develop transitions between main points to help the audience follow your presentation.
Structure a persuasive presentation with clear claim, reasons, evidence, and conclusion.
Plan the sequence of information to build toward your most important or convincing points.

sub_topics.name: Supporting Claims with Evidence
sub_topics.short_description: Including relevant facts, definitions, details, and examples to support main ideas.
example_tasks: Include at least three pieces of evidence (statistics, examples, expert quotes) for each main point in your presentation.
Cite sources orally when presenting information from research ('According to...', 'A study by...').
Use specific examples and details rather than general statements in your presentation.
Select the most compelling evidence from your research to include in a time-limited presentation.
Explain how each piece of evidence supports your claim or main point.

sub_topics.name: Creating Engaging Introductions and Conclusions
sub_topics.short_description: Beginning and ending presentations effectively to capture and maintain audience interest.
example_tasks: Begin a presentation with an attention-getting opening (question, surprising fact, relevant anecdote, quotation).
Clearly state your purpose or thesis early in your presentation.
End with a strong conclusion that reinforces your main message without simply repeating the introduction.
Conclude a persuasive speech with a clear call to action.
Create a conclusion that connects back to your opening and provides closure.

sub_topics.name: Delivering Presentations Effectively
sub_topics.short_description: Using appropriate eye contact, volume, pronunciation, and other delivery techniques.

sub_topics.name: Verbal Delivery Skills
sub_topics.short_description: Speaking clearly with appropriate volume, pace, pronunciation, and expression.
example_tasks: Practice speaking loudly and clearly enough for everyone in the room to hear comfortably.
Vary your pace to emphasize important points and maintain audience interest.
Pronounce words correctly, especially names and technical terms, practicing beforehand if needed.
Use appropriate pauses for emphasis and to give the audience time to process information.
Vary your tone and inflection to maintain interest and convey meaning rather than speaking in a monotone.

sub_topics.name: Nonverbal Communication
sub_topics.short_description: Using eye contact, gestures, posture, and facial expressions effectively.
example_tasks: Make eye contact with different audience members throughout your presentation.
Use natural gestures to emphasize points and maintain audience engagement.
Stand with confident posture rather than slouching or swaying.
Use facial expressions that match the content and tone of your presentation.
Move purposefully rather than pacing or standing rigidly in one spot.

sub_topics.name: Managing Presentation Anxiety
sub_topics.short_description: Using strategies to feel more confident and composed when presenting.
example_tasks: Practice your presentation multiple times to build confidence and familiarity with content.
Use deep breathing or other calming techniques before presenting.
Focus on communicating your message rather than on your nervousness.
Prepare thoroughly so you feel knowledgeable about your topic.
Remember that slight nervousness is normal and can actually energize your delivery.

sub_topics.name: Using Digital Media and Visual Displays
sub_topics.short_description: Integrating multimedia and visual elements strategically to enhance presentations.

sub_topics.name: Creating Effective Slides and Visuals
sub_topics.short_description: Designing visual aids that clarify and enhance rather than distract from the presentation.
example_tasks: Create slides with clear, readable text (large font, simple backgrounds, limited words per slide).
Use images, charts, or graphs that genuinely illustrate or clarify your points.
Avoid overcrowding slides with too much text or too many visual elements.
Use consistent design elements (colors, fonts, layouts) throughout your presentation.
Include only information on slides that supports your oral presentation rather than duplicating your script.

sub_topics.name: Integrating Multimedia Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Using audio, video, and other media to enhance understanding and engagement.
example_tasks: Include a relevant video clip that illustrates a key point in your presentation.
Use audio recordings (music, speeches, sound effects) to enhance specific moments.
Integrate multimedia smoothly so technical elements enhance rather than interrupt your presentation.
Ensure all multimedia elements work properly by testing equipment before presenting.
Explain how multimedia elements connect to and support your main points.

sub_topics.name: Presenting Data Visually
sub_topics.short_description: Using charts, graphs, and infographics to present information clearly.
example_tasks: Create charts or graphs that make statistical information easier to understand than numbers alone.
Choose the appropriate type of graph (bar, line, pie) for the data you're presenting.
Label charts and graphs clearly so the audience can understand them quickly.
Explain visual data presentations orally, highlighting key trends or significant information.
Use visual representations to compare information or show relationships clearly.

sub_topics.name: Adapting Speech to Context and Task
sub_topics.short_description: Adjusting language, style, and content based on purpose, audience, and situation.

sub_topics.name: Using Formal and Informal Language Appropriately
sub_topics.short_description: Choosing appropriate register and vocabulary for different speaking situations.
example_tasks: Use formal language and academic vocabulary when presenting research or making formal speeches.
Adjust your language to be more conversational when appropriate (discussions, informal presentations).
Avoid slang and casual expressions in formal presentations and academic contexts.
Use appropriate greeting and closing language for different speaking situations.
Recognize when humor, personal anecdotes, or casual language is appropriate versus when it's not.

sub_topics.name: Considering Audience Needs
sub_topics.short_description: Adapting content and delivery based on audience knowledge and interests.
example_tasks: Define technical terms when presenting to an audience unfamiliar with your topic.
Adjust the complexity of your language based on your audience's age and background knowledge.
Include background information for audiences who may be unfamiliar with your topic.
Consider what examples and evidence will be most convincing or relevant to your specific audience.
Anticipate and address questions or objections your particular audience might have.

sub_topics.name: Adapting to Purpose
sub_topics.short_description: Adjusting approach based on whether the purpose is to inform, persuade, or entertain.
example_tasks: Use objective language and focus on facts when the purpose is to inform.
Include persuasive appeals and calls to action when the purpose is to persuade.
Use engaging stories, humor, or creative elements when appropriate to the purpose.
Match your tone and style to your purpose (serious for formal informative, passionate for persuasive).
Structure your presentation differently based on purpose (comparison for informative, problem-solution for persuasive).

sub_topics.name: Demonstrating Command of Formal English
sub_topics.short_description: Using standard English grammar and conventions when presenting formally.

sub_topics.name: Using Grammatically Correct Speech
sub_topics.short_description: Applying standard English grammar rules in formal speaking situations.
example_tasks: Use complete sentences rather than fragments when presenting formally.
Ensure subject-verb agreement in formal presentations ('The data show...' not 'The data shows...').
Use correct pronoun case (I/me, who/whom) in formal speech.
Avoid double negatives and other nonstandard constructions in formal contexts.
Self-correct grammatical errors during presentations when you notice them.

sub_topics.name: Using Precise and Appropriate Language
sub_topics.short_description: Choosing specific, accurate words and avoiding vague or imprecise language.
example_tasks: Replace vague words (thing, stuff, a lot) with specific, precise alternatives in formal presentations.
Use domain-specific vocabulary correctly when presenting on academic topics.
Avoid filler words (um, like, you know) in formal presentations through practice.
Use transitional phrases that clearly show relationships between ideas.
Employ varied and sophisticated vocabulary appropriate to the topic and audience.

name: Literary Elements and Devices
short_description: Students identify and analyze how authors use various literary elements and devices to create meaning, develop themes, and enhance their writing. They understand how these techniques work together to create effective literature.

sub_topics.name: Figurative Language
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how authors use nonliteral language to create imagery, convey meaning, and enhance expression.

sub_topics.name: Metaphors and Similes
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and interpreting comparisons that create vivid imagery and convey complex ideas.
example_tasks: Identify similes and metaphors in a passage and explain what two things are being compared.
Analyze what a metaphor reveals about a character or situation that literal language would not.
Explain how an extended metaphor develops throughout a chapter or entire work.
Compare how two authors use different metaphors to describe similar experiences or emotions.
Create your own metaphors and similes to describe abstract concepts or complex feelings.

sub_topics.name: Personification
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how giving human qualities to nonhuman things creates meaning and effect.
example_tasks: Identify examples of personification in a text where natural elements or objects are given human characteristics.
Explain how personification helps readers connect emotionally to abstract concepts or nature.
Analyze how personification contributes to the mood or atmosphere in a descriptive passage.
