Compare personification in poetry versus prose and how it functions differently in each.
Explain how personification can make settings or objects feel alive and significant to the story.

sub_topics.name: Hyperbole and Understatement
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing exaggeration and deliberate minimization used for emphasis or effect.
example_tasks: Identify hyperbole in a text and explain what is being exaggerated and why.
Analyze how hyperbole creates humor or emphasizes the intensity of emotions or situations.
Recognize understatement and explain how minimizing something creates ironic or subtle effects.
Compare the effects of hyperbole versus understatement in different passages.
Explain how context determines whether exaggeration is hyperbole or literal description.

sub_topics.name: Symbolism and Allegory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how objects, characters, or events represent larger ideas beyond their literal meaning.

sub_topics.name: Identifying and Interpreting Symbols
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing when objects or images represent abstract ideas or themes.
example_tasks: Identify a recurring object or image in a story and explain what larger idea it might symbolize.
Analyze how the meaning of a symbol develops or changes throughout a text.
Explain how symbols enhance theme by representing abstract concepts concretely.
Compare how the same symbol (e.g., water, light, a journey) represents different things in different texts.
Distinguish between objects that are simply part of the setting and those that function symbolically.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Allegory
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing when entire narratives represent abstract ideas or moral lessons.
example_tasks: Identify allegorical elements in a fable or parable where characters represent abstract qualities.
Explain what real-world situation or moral truth an allegorical story represents.
Analyze how different characters in an allegory represent different aspects of human nature or society.
Compare a straightforward narrative with an allegorical one on a similar theme.
Explain how allegory allows authors to comment on society or morality indirectly.

sub_topics.name: Irony
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and analyzing situations where meaning differs from or contradicts expectations or literal statements.

sub_topics.name: Verbal Irony and Sarcasm
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing when characters say the opposite of what they mean.
example_tasks: Identify examples of verbal irony where a character's words contradict their intended meaning.
Distinguish between gentle verbal irony and harsh sarcasm based on context and tone.
Explain how verbal irony reveals a character's true feelings or attitude.
Analyze how authors use verbal irony to create humor or social commentary.
Identify clues in context that signal when statements should be interpreted ironically.

sub_topics.name: Situational Irony
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding when outcomes are the opposite of what was expected.
example_tasks: Identify situational irony where events turn out contrary to what characters or readers expected.
Explain how situational irony creates surprise, disappointment, or dark humor.
Analyze how an ironic outcome reveals theme or character truth.
Compare situations where characters get what they want versus what they need (ironic outcome).
Explain how situational irony makes a story more complex or thought-provoking.

sub_topics.name: Dramatic Irony
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing when readers know something important that characters do not.
example_tasks: Identify dramatic irony where the audience knows information that characters lack.
Explain how dramatic irony creates suspense or tension as readers anticipate consequences.
Analyze how dramatic irony affects reader sympathy toward characters.
Describe how an author creates dramatic irony through point of view or information timing.
Explain the emotional effect of watching characters act on incomplete or incorrect information.

sub_topics.name: Tone, Mood, and Atmosphere
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how authors create emotional effects through word choice, imagery, and other techniques.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Author's Tone
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing the author's or narrator's attitude toward the subject or audience.
example_tasks: Identify the tone of a passage (serious, humorous, sarcastic, nostalgic, etc.) based on word choice and details.
Explain how specific words and phrases create or reinforce the author's tone.
Trace how tone shifts during a text and what causes those changes.
Compare how two authors use different tones when writing about similar subjects.
Analyze how tone affects how readers respond to characters or events.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Mood and Atmosphere
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how authors create emotional atmosphere that affects readers.
example_tasks: Describe the mood (emotional atmosphere) created in a scene and identify what creates it.
Analyze how setting details, imagery, and word choice work together to create mood.
Explain how mood changes between different scenes or sections of a text.
Compare how different authors create similar moods (suspense, peace, dread) using different techniques.
Identify specific words and phrases that contribute most strongly to mood.

sub_topics.name: Foreshadowing and Suspense
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how authors hint at future events and create anticipation in readers.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Foreshadowing
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing clues and hints about events that will occur later in the story.
example_tasks: Identify early details in a story that foreshadow later events or outcomes.
Explain how dialogue, descriptions, or events hint at what will happen later.
Analyze how foreshadowing creates a sense of inevitability or impending doom.
Trace how subtle foreshadowing early in a text becomes clear only after later events.
Distinguish between obvious foreshadowing and subtle hints that require careful reading.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Analyzing Suspense
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how authors build tension and anticipation about outcomes.
example_tasks: Identify techniques an author uses to create suspense (pacing, withholding information, raising questions).
Explain how cliffhangers at chapter or section ends maintain reader interest.
Analyze how the author balances revealing and concealing information to maintain suspense.
Describe how time pressure or mounting obstacles increase suspense.
Compare how suspense functions differently in mysteries versus other genres.

sub_topics.name: Allusion and Literary Reference
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing and interpreting references to other texts, historical events, or cultural knowledge.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Allusions
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing references to mythology, literature, history, religion, or popular culture.
example_tasks: Identify allusions to mythology, the Bible, or historical events in a text.
Recognize references to other literary works (Shakespearean phrases, fairy tales, famous novels).
Identify allusions to historical figures or events and explain their relevance.
Recognize pop culture references that would be familiar to the text's original audience.
Use footnotes, research, or context to understand unfamiliar allusions.

sub_topics.name: Interpreting the Meaning of Allusions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how allusions add layers of meaning and enrich interpretation.
example_tasks: Explain how an allusion to a mythological story enriches the meaning of a character or situation.
Analyze how understanding a historical allusion changes your interpretation of a passage.
Describe what additional meaning a literary allusion brings to a text.
Compare a character's situation with the mythological or historical figure they're compared to through allusion.
Explain how allusions create connections between texts and broaden thematic resonance.

name: Narrative Techniques and Story Elements
short_description: Students analyze how authors construct narratives through plot structure, characterization, point of view, setting, and conflict. They understand how narrative choices affect reader experience and meaning.

sub_topics.name: Plot Structure and Development
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how narratives are organized and how events build toward climax and resolution.

sub_topics.name: Elements of Plot
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying exposition, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution in narratives.
example_tasks: Create a plot diagram for a short story identifying all five elements of plot structure.
Explain what essential information is provided in the exposition of a novel.
Identify the climax of a story and explain why this moment is the turning point.
Analyze how the author builds tension during the rising action through complications and obstacles.
Describe how the resolution addresses the main conflict and provides closure.

sub_topics.name: Pacing and Narrative Time
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how authors control the speed at which events unfold.
example_tasks: Identify sections where the author slows down pacing through detailed description or reflection.
Analyze where the author speeds up pacing through summarizing events or using short sentences.
Explain how pacing changes between action scenes and quieter, reflective moments.
Describe how time is compressed or extended in different parts of a narrative.
Analyze how pacing contributes to suspense, mood, or emphasis on important events.

sub_topics.name: Flashbacks and Non-Linear Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how stories can depart from chronological order.
example_tasks: Identify flashbacks and explain what background information they provide.
Analyze why an author chooses to begin a story in the middle (in medias res) rather than at the beginning.
Trace the chronological order of events in a story told through multiple time periods.
Explain how a frame story (story within a story) structure affects the narrative.
Analyze how non-chronological storytelling creates mystery or emphasizes certain themes.

sub_topics.name: Characterization and Character Development
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how authors create and develop characters through various techniques.

sub_topics.name: Direct and Indirect Characterization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how authors reveal character through explicit description and implicit methods.
example_tasks: Identify examples of direct characterization where the narrator explicitly describes a character's traits.
Analyze indirect characterization through a character's actions, speech, thoughts, and interactions.
Explain what a character's dialogue reveals about their personality, background, or education.
Describe what you learn about a character from how other characters respond to or describe them.
Analyze how physical descriptions and appearance details contribute to characterization.

sub_topics.name: Types of Characters
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between protagonist, antagonist, major, minor, static, and dynamic characters.
example_tasks: Identify the protagonist and antagonist in a story and explain their opposing goals.
Distinguish between major characters (fully developed, important to plot) and minor characters (less developed).
Determine whether a character is static (unchanging) or dynamic (undergoes significant change).
Identify round characters (complex, realistic) versus flat characters (one-dimensional).
Explain the function of foil characters who contrast with main characters to highlight their traits.

sub_topics.name: Character Motivation
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing what drives characters' decisions and actions.
example_tasks: Identify a character's main motivation (what they want or need) and how it drives the plot.
Analyze how a character's background or past experiences influence their current motivations.
Explain how internal motivations (emotions, desires) conflict with external circumstances.
Trace how a character's motivations change or evolve throughout the story.
Compare the motivations of different characters and how they create conflict.

sub_topics.name: Character Arc and Development
sub_topics.short_description: Tracing how characters change and grow over the course of a narrative.
example_tasks: Create a character development chart showing how a protagonist changes from beginning to end.
Identify the experiences or events that cause a character to change or grow.
Analyze what a character learns about themselves or the world through their journey.
Explain how internal conflicts contribute to character development.
Compare a character's beliefs, values, or behavior at the start versus the end of the story.

sub_topics.name: Point of View and Narrator
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how narrative perspective shapes the reader's experience and access to information.

sub_topics.name: Types of Narration
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying first-person, second-person, and third-person narration and their effects.
example_tasks: Identify whether a story uses first-person (I/we), second-person (you), or third-person (he/she/they) narration.
Distinguish between third-person limited (one character's perspective) and omniscient (all-knowing narrator).
Explain what information readers have access to based on the point of view used.
Analyze how first-person narration creates intimacy and limits perspective simultaneously.
Compare how the same scene would feel different told from a different point of view.

sub_topics.name: Reliable and Unreliable Narrators
sub_topics.short_description: Evaluating whether narrators can be trusted to present events accurately.
example_tasks: Identify clues that suggest a narrator might be unreliable (contradictions, bias, limited knowledge).
Analyze how an unreliable narrator creates uncertainty or requires readers to read between the lines.
Explain what might cause a narrator to be unreliable (youth, mental state, bias, deception).
Compare what a narrator says happened with evidence in the story of what actually happened.
Discuss how discovering a narrator is unreliable changes your interpretation of events.

sub_topics.name: Multiple Narrators and Perspectives
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing stories told from multiple viewpoints.
example_tasks: Compare how different narrators describe the same event and what this reveals about each character.
Analyze how multiple perspectives provide a more complete picture of events than a single viewpoint could.
Explain how different characters' perspectives reveal their biases, priorities, and limitations.
Trace how your understanding of events develops as you encounter different narrators' accounts.
Analyze why an author chose to tell a story from multiple perspectives rather than just one.

sub_topics.name: Setting and Its Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how time, place, and social context affect narratives.

sub_topics.name: Elements of Setting
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying the time period, geographical location, and social environment of a story.
example_tasks: Describe the time period of a story and what historical details reveal this.
Identify the geographical and physical setting and how it's established through details.
Analyze the social and cultural context (customs, values, social structures) of the story's world.
Explain how the author uses sensory details to make the setting vivid and concrete.
Compare how setting differs in various parts of the story as characters move or time passes.

sub_topics.name: How Setting Influences Story
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the relationship between setting and plot, character, or theme.
example_tasks: Explain how the setting creates obstacles or opportunities for characters.
Analyze how the time period affects what choices are available to characters.
Describe how the physical environment reflects or contrasts with characters' emotional states.
Explain how the story would be fundamentally different if set in a different time or place.
Analyze how setting contributes to mood, atmosphere, or theme in the story.

sub_topics.name: Setting as Symbol
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding when setting represents larger ideas beyond its literal function.
example_tasks: Identify aspects of setting that function symbolically (a storm representing turmoil, a garden representing growth).
Analyze how contrasting settings (city vs. country, light vs. dark spaces) represent opposing values or ideas.
Explain how the setting reflects the internal landscape of characters' minds or emotions.
Describe how changes in setting parallel or represent character development or thematic shifts.
Analyze how a confined or isolated setting symbolizes characters' psychological or social situations.

sub_topics.name: Conflict
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and analyzing the struggles that drive narratives forward.

sub_topics.name: Types of Conflict
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying external and internal conflicts in narratives.
example_tasks: Identify the main external conflict (character vs. character, character vs. society, character vs. nature).
Identify internal conflicts where characters struggle with their own emotions, beliefs, or decisions.
Explain how a character faces both external obstacles and internal doubts or conflicts.
Analyze how different types of conflict interact (external conflict creating internal conflict, for example).
Compare the primary conflict with secondary conflicts in a story.

sub_topics.name: Conflict Development and Resolution
sub_topics.short_description: Tracing how conflicts intensify and are ultimately resolved or transformed.
example_tasks: Trace how a conflict develops from its introduction through complications to climax.
Analyze what events or decisions escalate the conflict to make it more intense.
Explain how the main conflict is resolved and whether the resolution is satisfying.
Identify whether conflicts are fully resolved or left ambiguous at the story's end.
Analyze how resolving external conflicts relates to resolving internal conflicts.

name: Fiction Genres and Forms
short_description: Students explore different genres of fiction, understanding the conventions, purposes, and characteristic elements of each. They analyze how genre expectations shape both writing and reading experiences.

sub_topics.name: Realistic Fiction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding stories set in contemporary or recent past with believable characters and events.

sub_topics.name: Contemporary Realistic Fiction
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing stories that reflect current times and real-world issues.
example_tasks: Identify how a realistic fiction story addresses contemporary issues relevant to middle school readers.
Analyze how characters face believable challenges similar to those real people encounter.
Explain how the author creates authentic dialogue and relationships between characters.
Compare how different realistic fiction books approach similar themes (friendship, family, identity).
Evaluate whether the resolution of a realistic fiction story feels authentic and earned.

sub_topics.name: Historical Realism and Accuracy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how realistic fiction creates believable settings and situations.
example_tasks: Identify details that make the setting of a realistic fiction story feel authentic.
Analyze how the author balances optimism with realistic portrayal of difficulties.
Evaluate whether characters' responses to problems are psychologically realistic.
Explain how realistic fiction can address serious topics while remaining appropriate for young readers.
Compare a realistic fiction portrayal of an issue with non-fiction accounts of similar situations.

sub_topics.name: Historical Fiction
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing narratives set in past time periods that blend historical facts with fictional elements.

sub_topics.name: Historical Accuracy in Fiction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how authors research and incorporate historical details authentically.
example_tasks: Identify historical details in a novel that accurately reflect the time period (clothing, technology, social customs).
Research a historical event portrayed in a novel and compare fictional portrayal with historical facts.
Analyze how an author weaves real historical events with fictional characters and plot.
Identify anachronisms (things that don't fit the time period) if any appear in historical fiction.
Explain what aspects of a historical fiction novel are factual versus imagined.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Historical Periods Through Fiction
sub_topics.short_description: Using historical fiction to gain insight into past eras and perspectives.
example_tasks: Explain what you learned about daily life in a historical period from reading historical fiction.
Analyze how historical fiction helps readers understand the perspectives and values of people in the past.
Compare how characters in historical fiction face constraints that don't exist in contemporary settings.
Identify how historical events shape characters' lives and choices in historical fiction.
Discuss how historical fiction can make historical events more personal and emotionally accessible than textbooks.

sub_topics.name: Fantasy and Science Fiction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding genres that incorporate imaginative elements beyond realistic settings.

sub_topics.name: Fantasy Conventions and World-Building
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how fantasy creates imaginary worlds with their own rules and logic.
example_tasks: Identify elements that make a story fantasy (magic, imaginary creatures, invented worlds).
Analyze how an author establishes the rules of magic or supernatural elements in a fantasy world.
Describe how detailed world-building makes a fantasy setting feel consistent and believable.
Explain how a fantasy quest or journey structure develops characters and themes.
Compare how different fantasy works use or subvert common fantasy tropes (chosen one, magical object, etc.).

sub_topics.name: Science Fiction and Speculative Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding stories based on scientific possibilities and futuristic scenarios.
example_tasks: Identify science fiction elements like advanced technology, space travel, or future societies.
Analyze how a science fiction story extrapolates from current technology or scientific knowledge.
Explain how science fiction uses imagined futures to comment on current society.
Compare dystopian science fiction with utopian visions of the future.
Analyze how science fiction explores ethical questions about technology and scientific progress.

sub_topics.name: Themes in Fantasy and Science Fiction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how imaginative genres address real-world themes and human experiences.
example_tasks: Identify universal themes (good vs. evil, power and responsibility, identity) in fantasy or science fiction.
Explain how fantastical elements serve as metaphors for real-world issues or experiences.
Analyze how science fiction explores consequences of technological or social changes.
Discuss how fantasy or science fiction settings allow authors to explore ideas that would be difficult in realistic fiction.
Compare how a theme is treated differently in realistic fiction versus fantasy or science fiction.

sub_topics.name: Mystery and Suspense
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing stories structured around solving puzzles or uncovering secrets.

sub_topics.name: Mystery Structure and Conventions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how mysteries present clues, red herrings, and solutions.
example_tasks: Identify the central mystery or puzzle that drives the plot forward.
Analyze how the author plants clues throughout the story that point toward the solution.
Identify red herrings (false clues) designed to mislead readers.
Explain how the detective or protagonist gathers and interprets information.
Evaluate whether the mystery's solution is fair (based on clues available to readers) or feels arbitrary.

sub_topics.name: Building Suspense and Tension
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing techniques for maintaining reader interest and anticipation.
example_tasks: Identify how the author creates suspense by withholding information or raising questions.
Analyze how pacing controls the release of information to maintain interest.
Explain how multiple suspects or possibilities keep readers guessing.
Describe how danger or time pressure increases tension in a mystery or thriller.
Analyze how the author balances revealing information with maintaining suspense until the end.

sub_topics.name: Adventure and Survival Stories
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding narratives focused on physical challenges and overcoming obstacles.

sub_topics.name: Adventure Story Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing journeys, quests, and physical challenges in adventure fiction.
example_tasks: Identify the quest or goal that drives an adventure story forward.
Analyze how the protagonist must use physical skills, courage, or resourcefulness to overcome obstacles.
Explain how the journey or adventure leads to character growth beyond just physical accomplishment.
Describe how exotic or challenging settings contribute to the adventure.
Compare different types of adventures (exploration, escape, rescue, quest) and their structures.

sub_topics.name: Survival Stories and Human Resilience
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding stories that focus on perseverance in extreme circumstances.
example_tasks: Analyze how a character must rely on their own skills and ingenuity to survive.
Identify what internal qualities (determination, creativity, hope) help characters survive physical challenges.
Explain how conflict with nature or environment creates both external and internal challenges.
Describe how survival stories explore themes of human resilience and adaptation.
Compare how different survival stories show characters learning from and being changed by their ordeals.

name: American Literature and Cultural Identity
short_description: Students explore American literary traditions, diverse voices, and how literature reflects and shapes American cultural identity. They analyze works from different periods, regions, and communities that contribute to the American literary canon.

sub_topics.name: Diverse American Voices and Perspectives
sub_topics.short_description: Reading and analyzing literature from diverse American communities and experiences.

sub_topics.name: Multicultural American Literature
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring works by authors from various ethnic, racial, and cultural backgrounds.
example_tasks: Read poetry or prose by African American authors and analyze themes of identity, heritage, and experience.
Analyze how Latino/Latina authors incorporate cultural traditions and bilingual elements in their writing.
Read works by Native American authors and discuss how they portray indigenous experiences and perspectives.
Explore Asian American literature and how it addresses themes of immigration, assimilation, and cultural identity.
Compare how authors from different cultural backgrounds approach similar themes like family, belonging, or the American Dream.

sub_topics.name: Regional American Voices
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how different regions of America are portrayed in literature.
example_tasks: Analyze how Southern literature portrays the culture, history, and landscape of the American South.
Read works set in different American regions and compare how setting shapes character and story.
Identify dialect and regional language in American literature and discuss its authenticity and purpose.
Analyze how urban versus rural settings are portrayed in American literature.
Compare historical and contemporary depictions of the same American region in literature.

sub_topics.name: Immigration and the American Experience
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring how literature portrays immigration and the immigrant experience in America.
example_tasks: Read narratives about immigration and analyze themes of cultural adaptation, identity, and belonging.
Analyze how characters navigate between their heritage culture and American culture.
Compare immigration stories from different time periods and cultural backgrounds.
Identify challenges and opportunities immigrants face as portrayed in American literature.
Discuss how immigration narratives contribute to understanding American identity as multicultural.

sub_topics.name: American Literary Periods and Movements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how American literature has evolved and responded to historical and social changes.

sub_topics.name: Early American and Colonial Literature
sub_topics.short_description: Introduction to foundational American texts and their historical contexts.
example_tasks: Read excerpts from early American documents or narratives and analyze their purposes and audiences.
Identify themes of freedom, opportunity, and new beginnings in early American writing.
Compare Native American oral traditions with European settler narratives.
Analyze how early American literature reflects the values and concerns of colonial society.
Discuss how early American texts established themes that continue in American literature.

sub_topics.name: 19th Century American Literature
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring Romantic, Transcendentalist, and Realist movements in American literature.
example_tasks: Read works by American Romantic authors and identify themes of nature, imagination, and emotion.
Analyze Transcendentalist ideas about individualism, nature, and social reform in essays or poetry.
Compare Romantic idealism with Realist depictions of everyday life and social issues.
Read literature addressing slavery and abolition and analyze its social and moral arguments.
Discuss how 19th-century literature reflects westward expansion and changing American identity.

sub_topics.name: Modern and Contemporary American Literature
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding 20th and 21st century American literature and its themes.
example_tasks: Read contemporary young adult literature and analyze how it addresses current issues facing adolescents.
Identify themes in modern American literature such as technology, diversity, social justice, and identity.
Compare how authors from different decades address similar themes (war, family, coming of age).
Analyze how contemporary literature incorporates diverse formats (verse novels, graphic novels, multimedia).
Discuss how recent American literature reflects current social movements and cultural conversations.

sub_topics.name: Themes and Values in American Literature
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing recurring themes that reflect American experiences, ideals, and conflicts.

sub_topics.name: The American Dream
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring how literature portrays ideals of opportunity, success, and upward mobility.
example_tasks: Analyze how different works portray the pursuit of the American Dream and whether characters achieve it.
Compare optimistic and critical portrayals of the American Dream in literature.
Discuss how the definition of the American Dream differs across time periods and communities.
Analyze barriers to achieving the American Dream as portrayed in various texts.
Examine how literature questions or affirms the reality of equal opportunity in America.

sub_topics.name: Freedom and Individualism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how American literature emphasizes personal liberty and self-reliance.
example_tasks: Analyze how characters assert their independence or rebel against authority.
Identify themes of self-reliance and individual responsibility in American texts.
Discuss how American literature balances individualism with community responsibility.
Compare how different authors portray the costs and benefits of independence.
Analyze how characters define freedom differently based on their circumstances and backgrounds.

sub_topics.name: Social Justice and Equality
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how literature addresses injustice, inequality, and struggles for civil rights.
example_tasks: Read literature addressing racial injustice and analyze how it portrays both oppression and resistance.
Analyze how authors use literature to advocate for social change and equality.
Identify how literature gives voice to marginalized communities and experiences.
Compare historical and contemporary literature addressing similar social justice issues.
Discuss how literature can raise awareness and inspire action on social issues.

sub_topics.name: Coming of Age and Identity Formation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how American literature portrays adolescence and the search for identity.
example_tasks: Analyze how young adult characters navigate challenges of growing up in American society.
Identify common stages or experiences in coming-of-age narratives across different works.
Discuss how characters' cultural backgrounds influence their identity formation.
Compare how different time periods and settings affect the coming-of-age experience.
Analyze how characters balance individual identity with family and cultural expectations.

sub_topics.name: American Literary Forms and Innovations
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring distinctive forms and styles in American literature.

sub_topics.name: The American Short Story
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the short story as a distinctly American literary form.
example_tasks: Read classic and contemporary American short stories and analyze their structure and techniques.
Compare how different American authors use the short story form to explore themes.
Analyze how short stories create complete narratives and character development in limited space.
Identify signature techniques of American short story writers (surprise endings, character revelation, social commentary).
Discuss how the short story form suits particular types of stories or themes.

sub_topics.name: American Poetry Traditions
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring diverse voices and forms in American poetry.
example_tasks: Read poetry by diverse American poets and analyze themes of American identity and experience.
Compare traditional forms with free verse in American poetry.
Analyze how American poets use colloquial language and American speech patterns.
Identify how American poetry addresses social issues, nature, and personal experience.
Compare poetry from different American literary movements (Romantic, Modernist, contemporary).

sub_topics.name: Contemporary and Innovative Forms
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding new and hybrid forms in contemporary American literature.
example_tasks: Read and analyze a verse novel and discuss how poetic form affects storytelling.
Explore graphic novels or illustrated narratives and analyze how text and images work together.
Analyze how contemporary literature incorporates technology and digital media.
Read examples of creative nonfiction or memoir and discuss how they blend literary techniques with true stories.
Compare traditional narrative forms with experimental or innovative contemporary forms.

name: World Literature and Global Perspectives
short_description: Students explore literature from diverse world cultures, understanding how literature reflects universal human experiences while honoring cultural differences. They make connections across cultures and recognize global themes.

sub_topics.name: Cultural Contexts in World Literature
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how literature reflects and is shaped by specific cultural contexts.

sub_topics.name: Reading Literature from Different Cultures
sub_topics.short_description: Approaching texts from unfamiliar cultures with openness and cultural awareness.
example_tasks: Read a story or novel from a non-Western culture and identify cultural elements that differ from your own experience.
Research the cultural and historical context of a world literature text to better understand it.
Identify values, beliefs, or customs reflected in a text from another culture.
Discuss how understanding cultural context enriches interpretation of a literary work.
Compare how similar themes (family, honor, coming of age) are treated differently in different cultural contexts.

sub_topics.name: Translation and Interpretation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how translation affects reading world literature.
example_tasks: Discuss how reading a work in translation differs from reading in the original language.
Compare different translations of the same work and identify differences in word choice or style.
Identify when cultural concepts in a text may not translate directly into English.
Appreciate the translator's role in making world literature accessible while preserving meaning.
Recognize that some nuances of language and culture may be lost or altered in translation.

sub_topics.name: Respecting Cultural Differences and Avoiding Stereotypes
sub_topics.short_description: Reading world literature with cultural sensitivity and avoiding generalizations.
example_tasks: Distinguish between individual characters' experiences and stereotypes about entire cultures.
Recognize that one text doesn't represent all people from a particular culture.
Approach unfamiliar cultural practices with curiosity rather than judgment.
Identify your own cultural assumptions and how they might affect your interpretation.
Discuss how literature can challenge stereotypes and provide nuanced cultural understanding.

sub_topics.name: Universal Themes in World Literature
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying common human experiences and themes across diverse cultural texts.

sub_topics.name: Shared Human Experiences
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing universal experiences portrayed across cultures.
example_tasks: Identify universal themes like love, loss, courage, or justice in texts from different cultures.
Compare how different cultures approach similar life experiences (birth, death, marriage, transitions).
Discuss how literature from diverse cultures reveals common human emotions and struggles.
Analyze how coming-of-age experiences are portrayed similarly and differently across cultures.
Identify moral or ethical questions that transcend cultural boundaries in world literature.

sub_topics.name: Cultural Variations on Universal Themes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how cultures express shared themes in culturally specific ways.
example_tasks: Compare how heroism is defined differently in texts from different cultural traditions.
Analyze how concepts of family and duty vary across cultures while remaining universally important.
Compare different cultural perspectives on relationships between individuals and community.
Discuss how justice and fairness are conceived differently in different cultural contexts.
Identify how storytelling traditions (oral, written, performance) vary across cultures.

sub_topics.name: World Literary Traditions and Forms
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring diverse literary traditions and forms from around the world.

sub_topics.name: Folktales, Myths, and Legends
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding traditional narratives from various world cultures.
example_tasks: Read folktales from different cultures and identify common patterns (trickster figures, moral lessons, magic).
Compare creation myths from different cultures and their cultural values.
Analyze how folktales preserve and transmit cultural values and wisdom.
Identify archetypal characters and situations that appear across different cultural traditions.
Discuss how traditional stories continue to influence contemporary literature and culture.

sub_topics.name: World Poetry Traditions
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring poetic forms and traditions from diverse cultures.
example_tasks: Read and analyze haiku from Japanese tradition and understand its form and focus on nature.
Explore poetry from different cultural traditions and compare themes and techniques.
Identify how different cultures use poetry for different purposes (celebration, mourning, protest, love).
Compare structured poetic forms from different cultures (sonnets, ghazals, haiku, tankas).
Analyze how oral poetry traditions differ from written poetry in various cultures.

sub_topics.name: Contemporary World Literature
sub_topics.short_description: Reading recent works from diverse global authors.
example_tasks: Read contemporary novels or stories from non-American authors and analyze global themes.
Identify how contemporary world literature addresses global issues (environment, technology, migration).
Compare how young people's experiences are portrayed in contemporary literature from different countries.
Discuss how globalization affects contemporary world literature and cross-cultural understanding.
Analyze how contemporary authors blend traditional cultural elements with modern global influences.

sub_topics.name: Comparative Approaches to World Literature
sub_topics.short_description: Making connections and comparisons across texts from different cultures.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Texts Across Cultures
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing similarities and differences between texts from different cultural origins.
example_tasks: Compare how two stories from different cultures approach the same theme or type of conflict.
Analyze how different cultural values lead to different resolutions in similar stories.
Compare protagonists from different cultural contexts facing similar challenges.
Identify what makes each text culturally specific versus what is universal.
Create a comparison chart showing how different cultures portray similar concepts or experiences.

sub_topics.name: Making Global Connections
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how world literature helps build cross-cultural understanding.
example_tasks: Discuss how reading world literature broadens perspective and challenges assumptions.
Identify connections between your own experiences and those of characters from different cultures.
Analyze how literature can build empathy and understanding across cultural differences.
Reflect on what you learned about another culture through reading its literature.
Discuss how world literature reveals both diversity and shared humanity.

name: Media Literacy and Multimodal Texts
short_description: Students analyze how meaning is created through various media and combinations of text, images, sound, and digital elements. They evaluate media messages critically and understand how different formats shape content and reception.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Visual Texts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how images, graphics, and visual design convey meaning.

sub_topics.name: Reading and Interpreting Images
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing photographs, illustrations, and other visual texts.
example_tasks: Analyze a photograph or illustration and describe what it communicates beyond its literal subject.
Identify the focal point of an image and explain how visual elements direct viewer attention.
Analyze how composition, lighting, and color in an image create mood or convey meaning.
Compare how different images represent the same subject and what each emphasizes.
Interpret symbolism or metaphorical meaning in visual images.

sub_topics.name: Graphic Novels and Visual Narratives
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how sequential art and text work together to tell stories.
example_tasks: Analyze how a graphic novel uses panel size, layout, and gutters (spaces between panels) to control pacing.
Explain how images and text work together to convey meaning that neither could alone.
Identify how visual elements (facial expressions, body language, symbols) develop character.
Analyze how color, shading, and artistic style contribute to mood and theme in a graphic novel.
Compare how the same story element would be conveyed in prose versus in graphic form.

sub_topics.name: Infographics and Data Visualization
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how visual design presents information and data.
example_tasks: Analyze an infographic and evaluate how effectively it presents complex information visually.
Identify what information is emphasized or de-emphasized through visual design choices.
Evaluate whether a data visualization accurately represents information or is misleading.
Compare how information presented in an infographic versus in text affects understanding.
Create your own simple infographic to present information visually.

sub_topics.name: Digital and Multimodal Texts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding texts that combine multiple modes of communication.

sub_topics.name: Websites and Digital Texts
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how digital texts use layout, links, and multimedia.
example_tasks: Analyze how a website's layout and navigation guide users through information.
Evaluate how hyperlinks create non-linear reading experiences and connections between ideas.
Identify how websites use text, images, and design elements together to convey messages.
Compare how information is presented differently on websites versus in print texts.
Analyze how website design reflects purpose (commercial, educational, entertainment, persuasive).

sub_topics.name: Video and Multimedia Texts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how video combines visual, audio, and textual elements.
example_tasks: Analyze how a video documentary uses narration, interviews, music, and visuals to make an argument.
Identify how editing choices (cuts, transitions, sequence) affect meaning in a video.
Explain how music and sound effects in a video enhance or alter the message.
Compare how the same information is presented in a video versus a written article.
Analyze how on-screen text, captions, or graphics complement or contrast with spoken content in a video.

sub_topics.name: Social Media and Digital Communication
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how social media platforms shape communication and messages.
example_tasks: Analyze how platform features (character limits, hashtags, sharing) affect how messages are crafted and spread.
Identify how images, emoji, and other visual elements convey meaning in social media posts.
Evaluate the credibility of information shared through social media.
Analyze how the same message might be adapted differently for different social media platforms.
Discuss how social media creates new forms of storytelling and self-expression.

sub_topics.name: Media Techniques and Persuasion
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and analyzing persuasive techniques used in various media.

sub_topics.name: Advertising and Marketing Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how advertisements use various strategies to persuade audiences.
example_tasks: Identify persuasive techniques in advertisements (emotional appeal, celebrity endorsement, bandwagon, etc.).
Analyze how advertisements target specific audiences through language, imagery, and appeals.
Evaluate the claims made in advertisements and identify what evidence is provided (or missing).
Compare how the same product is advertised differently to different demographic groups.
Analyze how advertisements use visual design, color, and composition to attract attention and create associations.

sub_topics.name: Propaganda and Bias in Media
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing bias, manipulation, and propaganda techniques in media messages.
example_tasks: Identify bias in media messages through word choice, image selection, and what information is included or omitted.
Recognize propaganda techniques like loaded language, oversimplification, or emotional manipulation.
Compare how different news sources present the same event and identify differences in perspective or bias.
Analyze how images can be selected or manipulated to create particular impressions.
Evaluate whether a media message presents information fairly or uses techniques to manipulate opinion.

sub_topics.name: Rhetorical Appeals in Media
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying ethos, pathos, and logos in various media formats.
example_tasks: Identify how media messages use emotional appeals (pathos) through images, music, or storytelling.
Analyze how media establishes credibility (ethos) through expert sources, data, or presenter authority.
Identify logical appeals (logos) using facts, statistics, and reasoning in media messages.
Evaluate the balance of different appeals in a persuasive media message.
Analyze whether emotional or logical appeals dominate in different types of media content.

sub_topics.name: Evaluating Media Sources and Messages
sub_topics.short_description: Developing critical skills to assess media credibility, purpose, and reliability.

sub_topics.name: Evaluating Source Credibility
sub_topics.short_description: Assessing whether media sources are trustworthy and reliable.
example_tasks: Evaluate a website's credibility by examining author credentials, publication date, domain, and purpose.
Identify signs of credible sources (citations, transparency about authorship, professional presentation).
Recognize warning signs of unreliable sources (sensational headlines, poor grammar, lack of citations).
Compare information from an unknown source with information from established, credible sources.
Research the background and reputation of a media source before trusting its information.

sub_topics.name: Fact-Checking and Verification
sub_topics.short_description: Using strategies to verify information accuracy in media.
example_tasks: Use fact-checking websites to verify claims made in media messages.
Trace information back to original sources to verify accuracy.
Identify when statistics or facts are presented without sources or context.
Compare how multiple credible sources report the same information to verify facts.
Recognize the difference between verified facts, opinions, and unsubstantiated claims.

sub_topics.name: Recognizing Misinformation and Disinformation
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying false or misleading information spread through media.
example_tasks: Distinguish between misinformation (false information spread unintentionally) and disinformation (deliberately false information).
Identify characteristics of fake news and manipulated media content.
Recognize when images, videos, or quotes are taken out of context to mislead.
Analyze why certain types of false information spread rapidly on social media.
Develop habits of verification before sharing information through social media.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Purpose and Intended Audience
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why media messages are created and who they target.
example_tasks: Identify whether a media message's primary purpose is to inform, entertain, persuade, or sell.
Analyze who the intended audience is based on language, images, and content choices.
Recognize when entertainment content also carries persuasive or commercial messages.
Identify sponsored content or native advertising disguised as news or entertainment.
Evaluate whether a media message achieves its purpose effectively for its target audience.

name: Critical Reading and Literary Criticism
short_description: Students develop skills in analytical reading and interpretation, learning to support interpretations with evidence and engage with different critical perspectives. They understand that texts can be read in multiple valid ways.

sub_topics.name: Close Reading and Textual Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Developing skills in careful, detailed reading and analysis of texts.

sub_topics.name: Annotation and Active Reading Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Using strategies to engage deeply with texts while reading.
example_tasks: Annotate a text by marking important passages, noting questions, and making connections.
Use symbols or codes to mark different types of information (themes, literary devices, questions, reactions).
Write marginal notes that question, analyze, or make connections to other texts or experiences.
Identify and mark patterns (repeated words, images, ideas) as you read.
Track character development or theme development through annotations across an entire text.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Specific Word Choices
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how individual word choices create meaning and effect.
example_tasks: Analyze why an author chose a particular word over its synonyms and what connotations it carries.
Identify patterns in diction (formal vs. informal, concrete vs. abstract, simple vs. complex).
Explain how word choice creates tone, mood, or characterization in specific passages.
Compare how changing one word in a sentence alters meaning or effect.
Analyze how an author's word choice reflects historical period, setting, or character voice.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Sentence and Paragraph Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how structure at the sentence and paragraph level creates meaning.
example_tasks: Analyze how sentence length and complexity affect pacing and emphasis in a passage.
Explain how paragraph structure develops and supports ideas.
Identify how topic sentences, supporting details, and transitions work within paragraphs.
Analyze how an author uses parallel structure for emphasis or comparison.
Examine how sentence fragments or non-standard syntax create specific effects.

sub_topics.name: Developing and Supporting Interpretations
sub_topics.short_description: Creating evidence-based interpretations of texts and defending them with reasoning.

sub_topics.name: Forming Literary Interpretations
sub_topics.short_description: Developing thoughtful, evidence-based interpretations of texts.
example_tasks: Develop an interpretation of a text's theme and identify specific evidence that supports it.
Create an interpretation of a character's motivation based on textual evidence.
Formulate an interpretation of a symbol's meaning and trace how it develops through the text.
Develop an explanation for an ambiguous or puzzling aspect of a text.
Create an interpretation that goes beyond surface-level or obvious meanings.

sub_topics.name: Supporting Interpretations with Evidence
sub_topics.short_description: Using specific textual evidence and reasoning to support interpretations.
example_tasks: Support your interpretation with direct quotations from the text and explain how they support your claim.
Use multiple pieces of evidence from different parts of the text to support an interpretation.
Explain the reasoning that connects your evidence to your interpretation.
Anticipate and address potential counterarguments to your interpretation.
Distinguish between strong evidence that directly supports your interpretation and weaker, less relevant evidence.

sub_topics.name: Revising and Refining Interpretations
sub_topics.short_description: Adjusting interpretations based on new evidence or perspectives.
example_tasks: Revise your initial interpretation after discussing the text with others or rereading carefully.
Adjust your interpretation when you encounter evidence that contradicts or complicates it.
Refine a general interpretation to make it more specific and nuanced.
Acknowledge complexity and ambiguity rather than forcing simple interpretations.
Recognize when multiple interpretations can be valid if supported by evidence.

sub_topics.name: Considering Multiple Perspectives and Interpretations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that texts can be interpreted in various valid ways.

sub_topics.name: Exploring Alternative Interpretations
sub_topics.short_description: Considering different ways of understanding the same text.
example_tasks: Identify at least two different valid interpretations of a text's theme or ending.
Explain how the same textual evidence could support different interpretations.
Consider how different readers might interpret a text differently based on their backgrounds or perspectives.
Evaluate which interpretation of a text you find most convincing and why.
Discuss how ambiguity in a text allows for multiple interpretations.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Textual Ambiguity
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing when texts deliberately leave meanings open to interpretation.
example_tasks: Identify aspects of a text that are deliberately ambiguous or open-ended.
Explain why an author might choose to leave certain elements ambiguous.
Discuss how ambiguous endings affect reader response and interpretation.
Analyze how symbolism can be ambiguous, carrying multiple potential meanings.
Distinguish between ambiguity that enriches a text and confusion caused by poor writing.

sub_topics.name: Reader Response and Personal Connections
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how readers' own experiences affect interpretation while staying grounded in the text.
example_tasks: Reflect on how your own experiences and background affect how you interpret a text.
Identify personal connections to a text while distinguishing between text-based and personal responses.
Discuss how different readers might respond differently to the same text based on their experiences.
Explain the difference between a personal response and a text-based interpretation.
Use personal connections to deepen engagement while supporting interpretations with textual evidence.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Literary Criticism Approaches
sub_topics.short_description: Beginning to understand different lenses or approaches for analyzing literature.

sub_topics.name: Biographical and Historical Approaches
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how author's life and historical context inform interpretation.
example_tasks: Research an author's biography and identify how their life experiences may have influenced their work.
Analyze how understanding the historical period when a text was written enriches interpretation.
Identify references to historical events or social conditions in a literary text.
Compare what a text reveals about its historical period with what you learn from history texts.
Discuss the benefits and limitations of focusing on biography or history when interpreting literature.

sub_topics.name: Thematic and Archetypal Approaches
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing universal themes and recurring patterns in literature.
example_tasks: Identify archetypal characters (hero, mentor, trickster) or situations (quest, journey) in a text.
Analyze how a text addresses universal themes that appear across cultures and time periods.
Compare how different texts use similar archetypal patterns or symbols.
Identify mythological or fairy tale patterns that appear in contemporary literature.
Discuss how archetypal approaches help connect literature across different periods and cultures.

sub_topics.name: Textual/Formalist Approaches
sub_topics.short_description: Focusing on how the text itself creates meaning through literary elements.
example_tasks: Analyze a text focusing exclusively on its language, structure, and literary devices without reference to outside context.
Explain how various literary elements work together to create a unified artistic whole.
Analyze patterns of imagery, symbolism, or structure within a text.
Focus on what the text itself reveals without relying on author biography or historical context.
Discuss how close attention to the text's formal elements deepens understanding.

sub_topics.name: Social and Cultural Approaches
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how literature reflects and comments on social issues and cultural values.
example_tasks: Analyze how a text portrays social class, gender roles, or racial dynamics.
Identify how literature reflects or challenges the values of the society in which it was written.
Examine how power relationships between groups are portrayed in a text.
Analyze whose voices and perspectives are represented or absent in a text.
Discuss how literature can both reflect and critique social conditions and cultural assumptions.

sub_topics.name: Engaging in Literary Discussions and Debates
sub_topics.short_description: Participating in thoughtful conversations about literature and defending interpretations.

sub_topics.name: Participating in Literature Circles and Discussions
sub_topics.short_description: Engaging productively in collaborative literary analysis.
example_tasks: Prepare discussion questions or observations about a text before meeting with your group.
Take on different roles in literature circles (discussion leader, passage selector, connector, questioner).
Build on others' interpretations by adding evidence or alternative perspectives.
Ask questions that push the group to think more deeply about the text.
Synthesize multiple perspectives from a discussion to develop a richer understanding.

sub_topics.name: Defending and Debating Interpretations
sub_topics.short_description: Articulating and supporting interpretations in dialogue with others.
example_tasks: Defend your interpretation of a text against someone who disagrees, using evidence and reasoning.
Acknowledge strengths in an alternative interpretation while explaining why you find yours more convincing.
Modify your interpretation based on compelling evidence or reasoning from others.
Distinguish between matters of interpretation (debatable) and matters of fact (verifiable in text).
Engage respectfully in interpretive disagreements, focusing on evidence rather than opinions.
